The date February 29 2000 has been identified as a potential trouble spot. Financial markets in Tokyo, New York and most European cities were yesterday undergoing dummy runs of their vast computer networks as final preparation for the first day's trading of the millennium. Only minor problems, including glitches in the trading systems of 12 Japanese brokerages, emerged but the real test will come as millions of financial staff begin real work. Margaret Draper, at the US Securities Industry Association, said: 'There have been no glitches or significant Y2K-related problems and we expect to start business as usual first thing in the morning.' Paris, Berlin and Milan made similar reports. In London, which has another day off, around 60,000 staff were drafted in at the weekend to watch for trouble and run final tests. One investment banker who had brought in books and videos to keep himself busy said that dress rehearsals had been running hitch free since the summer. The Financial Services Authority, which is operating a 24-hour millennium office, reported no problems with the banking system. Cash machines are working as normal while gas, water, electricity and telecommunications passed into 2000 without interuption. The ministry of agriculture said food retailers would open today as usual and that stock ordering systems and deliveries were working smoothly. Robin Guenier, director of the independent watchdog Taskforce 2000, said he was cautiously optimistic. 'It is not by any means just about the date rollover but that having gone smoothly is a pretty good indicator. We will learn a lot from what happens in the US financial markets today.' The London stock exchange, which reopens tomorrow, was yesterday making sure that links to around 200 broking firms and data providers such as Reuters were running smoothly. Reports from around the world suggested remarkably few instances of the bug biting, certainly nothing near the epidemic some had feared as a result of some computers recognising the digits 00 as 1900 instead of 2000. There was disquiet among some businesses that the bill for tuning up their computer systems could have been avoided. However, John Koskinen, chairman of the US president's council of Y2K conversion, said that the sum, spent on preventing problems, estimated by the government at $100bn (£62.5bn) and by private analysts as much more, was important because of the US dependence on computers. The government reported a problem with a spy satellite on Friday night. The satellite was put out of action for a few hours but was working on reduced capacity by Saturday. The British government has spent £430m on updating systems in the public sector. Mike Granatt, of the government's millennium office, said: 'There were very real problems which needed to be addressed. Things don't go right by accident.' Among the minor glitches was the failure of heart monitoring equipment in three Swedish hospitals understood to be millennium bug related. In Japan, computer malfunctions at two nuclear power plants, one confirmed as bug related, have been cleared up and did not affect safety or power generation, the company said. Italy, internationally chastised for doing too little preparation, hailed the lack of problems as a vindication. 'Millennium bug fears were swept away thanks to our excellent preparation and organization,' said Francesco Rutelli, the mayor of Rome. Paddy Tipping, minister with responsibility for the millennium bug, said the government's investment had been well spent. 'We have had a good millennium, but January 4 could be a critical day, when businesses go back to work. 'We may see some small businesses who have not prepared lose some information.' Stock markets in Australia, New Zealand, Israel and Thailand said systems had been given the all clear, while some smaller markets, including Cairo and Kuwait, were open for business and reported no problems.

webTitle: BBC wins Big Ben ratings battle

fields.bodyText: As with all landmark events, so it was with the turn of the millennium: Britain turned to the BBC. At midnight, some 19m people broke away from their parties to catch the millennium moment, and 12.6m chose to share it with Gaby Roslin and Michael Parkinson, who by this time were only halfway through the BBC's 28-hour broadcast, 2000 Today. Four million heard Big Ben bong with Trevor McDonald and the ITN team on ITV, while the rest were divided between the other channels. The BBC, predictably, was ecstatic - the preliminary figures were more than double last year's. Alan Yentob, the BBC's director of television, was not understated in his delight: '2000 Today has been an unprecedented success. The power of BBC television has united the whole world.' ITV was magnanimous in defeat. 'At moments of national significance, it's right that the BBC, as national broadcaster, should be pre-eminent,' said a spokeswoman. ITV had not tried to compete, she added. Instead it provided alternative entertainment for people who wanted something different. It had only switched to millennium mode at about 10pm, 'so ITV viewers didn't miss anything'. Sky News, which offered Frank Partridge and Kay Burley in a virtual reality set 'from the skies over London' - actually a warehouse in Osterley - and links to the dome, said it was pleased with its coverage, but had no figures available. In the end, it was the BBC's day - and night, and next morning. Which was just as well, since it had spent millions on its longest-ever live broadcast. Up to 5,000 staff worked on 2000 Today, 1,500 of them in television centre in west London, where all eight television studios were used.

Russian forces moved into the second week of their ground assault on the Chechen capital, Grozny, at the weekend, claiming that the rebel fighters, who were well dug in in the city, were using chemical weapons to halt the advance. While the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, delivered a new year appeal for an end to Russian 'barbarism' and announced that the Chechens were launching a full-scale guerrilla war, the Russians sent wave after wave of bombers over Grozny and said that they had captured strategic heights in the mountainous south of the breakaway republic. The Russian prime minister, Vladimir Putin, used the first full day of his acting presidency, following Boris Yeltsin's dramatic resignation on New Year's Eve, to make a lightning visit to Russian troops in occupied Chechnya, handing out medals, hunting knives - and tough rhetoric. Reports from Grozny spoke of dozens of air strikes on the city as well as hundreds of shells raining down. The Russians said they had broken through rebel positions two miles from the city centre - but there was little sign of any imminent breakthrough in Moscow's campaign to capture the Chechen capital. 'We have no intention of liberating anything by acting hastily,' Mr Putin said. 'We plan to act in the best possible way, which means as few losses as possible among our servicemen and no losses among the civilian population.' Mr Putin, who was told on Saturday by the US president, Bill Clinton, that Russo-American relations were 'off to a good start' in the post-Yeltsin era, reasserted that 'everything we have done so far [in Chechnya] has been justified'. But while the civilian casualty toll in Grozny was unclear, the number of Russian deaths is mounting. Since August, when Mr Putin became prime minister and the conflict erupted in Dagestan, neighbouring Chechnya, the Russians have lost 550 men. That is the official figure - but the Association of Soldiers' Mothers' Committees says the real death toll is three times as high. Every day this week, the military hospital at Mozdok has been taking delivery of about 30 severely wounded Russian soldiers from Grozny. Russian military sources alleged, not for the first time, that the rebels in Grozny were using chemical weapons. A green cloud of toxic gases, formed by chlorine and ammonia, was billowing over the east of the city, the Russians claimed. The Chechens were said to be igniting storage tanks filled with chemicals to slow down the Russian advance. Fierce fighting raged all weekend in the mountainous south, where resistance is strongest and where the guerrillas have their main shelters. The Russians said they flew 100 sorties over the region. The Chechens said they beat back a Russian attempt to take the village of Duba-Yurt. The Russians reported a big battle at Serzhen-Yurt and said they took control of a strategic position overlooking Vedeno, the base of the Islamist guerrilla commander, Shamil Basayev. 'Never again in the 21st century should any state or nation have the right to murder another people. What Russia is doing today is barbarism,' said President Maskhadov in his new year address.

The government took the rare step yesterday of apologising to the thousands of people who had to wait for up to four hours before they were allowed to enter the Millennium Dome on New Year's Eve. Amid widespread criticism of the delays, which marred the event for many specially-invited guests, the minister responsible for the dome blamed "management problems". "It should never have taken as long as it did," the cabinet office minister, Lord Falconer of Thoroton, said. "I really apologise to all those people, both VIPs and ordinary people, left waiting." His remarks came as the royal family and political leaders took the spiritual lead in ecumenical services around the country. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh joined the prime minister Tony Blair and his wife Cherie at St Paul's cathedral in London, where the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, urged the congregation to remember the Christian values of love and faith in God. The religious services were overshadowed by the continuing fallout over delays at the dome which prompted Greg Dyke, the new director-general of the BBC, to complain to ministers after waiting for three hours at Stratford station, in east London. Lord Falconer did not apportion blame for the delays, but the finger was being pointed last night at the Metropolitan police which placed only one x-ray machine at Stratford station, where many of the dome's 10,500 guests passed through security checks. The mistake by the police compounded the earlier one by the New Millennium Experience Company which failed to mail out thousands of tickets for the opening ceremony on time. Guests who queued for hours for their tickets were then faced by another long queue to pass through the airport-style security system. Lord Falconer insisted last night that the delays had not marred the dome's opening ceremony. "There were glitches round the edges but the central achievement was very impressive," he said. "In many respects it was the best in the world. People at the dome were united - they were spirited, interested and humorous." Lord Falconer joined Mr Blair for yesterday's service at St Paul's, where they heard readings from Bunyan and TS Eliot by the actors Patricia Hodge and Richard Griffiths. Rap singers provided a contemporary touch to Cardiff's millennium service at the Tabernacle church, which was attended by the Prince of Wales and his sons princes William and Harry. In Belfast, the Duke of York joined 2,000 invited guests at the Waterfront hall. Afterwards he joined the Northern Ireland first minister David Trimble at a meeting with groups representing the victims of the Troubles. "I hope 2000 goes on being very happy over here," Prince Andrew said. "It's very important."

The Dome is up, running and magnificent. Richard Rogers has made a stunning architectural statement, matched by an equally impressive feat of engineering. To have constructed it to an unbreakable deadline and on budget was a considerable achievement. But, oh dear, the millennial show that opened it! You could not quarrel with the spectacle - the aerial acrobats, the indoor fireworks, the carnival dancing. They were indeed spectacular and made full use of the building's cathedral height and space. But what preceded it was vapid stuff. A thousand years of British culture? Let the mind feast on Shakespeare, Chaucer, Milton, Dickens, Paine, Mill, Auden, Pinter, Burns, Dylan Thomas, Wilfred Owen, Wordsworth and Keats. Let the ear revel in Byrd, Purcell, Elgar, Gilbert and Sullivan, Walton, Macmillan, Birtwistle and Benjamin. The eye could roam over Turner, Constable, Brunel, Norman Foster, Freud, Bacon, Inigo Jones, David Lean, Chris Ofili, Gainsborough and Capability Brown. We have all read enough millennial lists over the past month to double, treble and trump those names. What did we get? An Overture to The Dome, not by Birtwistle but by Jools Holland. A new piece To the Millennium not by Maxwell Davies but by a theatre composer called Jonathan Dove. A new royal fanfare by - wait for it - Richard Morris, who is apparently a commissioner of English Heritage. Holst, Britten and Handel got brief soundbites but Mick Hucknall topped the bill. A piece by John Tavener was confusingly squeezed in between Her Majesty and Auld Lang Syne. The Archbishop of Canterbury said a limp prayer and Stephen Fry cracked a joke about stroking little boys. You could not imagine the French or the Italians putting on such a show. There was something almost narcissistic in its amnesia. New Dome, New Millennium, New Labour, New Britain! Celebrate the brave new world and quietly bury the old. Think not of culture but the taste of the prime-time audience. Toast the e-future, sponsored by BSkyB and the Sun. Hand out damehoods to Julie, Shirley and Elizabeth. Arise Sir Norman! The prime minister reads history, even if he makes almost a fetish of the future over the past. But he leads an administration that many think borders on the Philistine. That should worry him, even if only because of the value of culture to education. Children watching the bland trickle on the 'One Amazing Night' could be forgiven for thinking Jools Holland represented the epitome of British musicianship and that we were a nation with no tradition of using words, paint, film, landscape or brick. Mr Blair can take the credit for promoting the Dome, but he should be alarmed by its potent as symbol for New Labour. On Millennium's Eve the Dome was an empty shell.

webTitle: A host of cheers, and few tears

fields.bodyText: London's central streets managed - just - to put a quart into a pint pot on millennium night, with a mixture of elation, terror and sudden pools of calm which the prime minister might have second thoughts about wanting to bottle. Good nature and a determination to have fun took the sting out of most of the worst moments, including scary crushes and tearful, exhausted queues as too many people - from an estimated 3m - tried to do the same thing at the same time. Deep wells of stoicism also came to the rescue, especially when a murk-hidden Concorde saluted the finally turning (but apparently still motionless) millennium wheel to countless, deeply satisfied comments of: "Isn't this so British?" Three people died - two heart attacks and an accidental drowning - but the toll and the 99 arrests were down on a conventional London New Year's Eve. Scotland Yard praised the "fantastic, calming effect" of the crowd's huge age range, with thousands of families bringing children and grandparents and a palpable sense of wanting others in the throng to have a good time. Champagne-clutching strangers carefully sidestepped a woman in a wheelchair and a man with white sticks at Blackfriars, and a huge reveller at the sphinx took off his millennium top hat and crouched down so that twins Peter and Kylie O'Neill from Bristol could watch for the river of fire (albeit in vain). Tempers did snap at a number of almost disastrous bottlenecks, with fighting at the Temple Embankment at 9.30pm and fury at a two-hour going-home jam between the Hayward Gallery and nearby Waterloo. Large groups also caused unintentional chaos, but other potential disasters brought out the best in the crowd. "It was frightening but amazing, both at the same time," said Patsy Hayes, a Bradford primary school teacher whose teenage nephew fainted in the crush in Trafalgar Square just before the weight of numbers stove in the front window of a chemist's shop. Glass fragments came down on her 10-year-old daughter Rosie, but a group of unknown lads instinctively formed a human shield. Chivalry "They just flung up their arms to stop the big bits of plate glass," said Mrs Hayes. "They got cut themselves, but what they did was typical of the positive feeling all night - you were scared but you felt you'd be looked-after and all right." Her shouts of "Man down! Help!" immediately brought a bottle of Appletize over the heads of the crowd to revive her nephew, followed within seconds by three police. Appletize was a rarity on a night which saw champagne bottles form an estimated 15% of the rubbish cleared on New Year's Day by 150 staff with 13 dustcarts and 18 mechanical sweepers on the Embankment alone. By 1am, a child pretending to tightrope along the gutter between the ministry of defence and the National Liberal Club would have been able to do so entirely on empty bottles, almost all champagne. Misery and comfort Drunkenness featured heavily in the arrests - 6% down on the same night in central London last year - but prompted more of a muzzy sense of bonhomie than laddish bullying. Youths who had been drinking heavily (between incoherent mobile phone calls to everyone they could think of) were instrumental in rapidly getting three police to an elderly man who collapsed at the end of Whitehall Place. There was criticism, however, of police tactics on the South Bank after Big Ben's chimes, inaudible even within 200 yards because of the cheers, whistles and a special toneless millennium horn available in job-lots from street-vendors. Brian Westra, whose family had come from Holland to see the river of fire, said that he was astonished to see mounted officers ride into a crush by Waterloo, terrifying a nine-year-old girl when one officer hit revellers who didn't move out of the way. The line between misery in a crush and comfort in a quiet oasis depended partly on luck and partly on local knowledge. At 11.30pm, scrambling through shrubbery took you from a packed, choking street off the Strand into Embankment Gardens, where families sat on uncrowded lawns like a Sunday school outing, apart from the dark and the champagne. Drink is thought to have been behind the drowning of a 23-year-old man whose body was recovered from the Thames at low tide yesterday, after one of his friends was rescued at Lambeth bridge soon after midnight. Two men died of heart attacks in York Road on the South Bank, where some of the worst crushes took place as people queued to catch trains home. A short distance up the Thames, St Thomas's hospital took 200 minor casualties after midnight and the London ambulance service had 2,300 calls in the first six hours of New Year's Day. The virtual lavatory-free zone along both riverbanks in central London was blamed for a significant number of collapses, and the stench from countless impromptu urinals was the authentic millennial smell. Underwritten by a drinks firm, the free Tube service home also had hiccups, but by 3am few had the energy to do more than groan weakly at news of a stranded train causing a one-station gap on the Northern Line. Thousands of partygoers ended the Great Night trekking in opposite directions along Pentonville Road, alternating between "Is this the way to King's Cross/the Angel?" with "Have a happy new year". What worked and failed on Millennium Eve: What worked: The Dome Edinburgh's Hogmanay The Eiffel Tower firework show The Queen kissing the Duke of Edinburgh Gaby Roslin's stimulants What didn't: The queues at the Dome Portaloos on the Embankment London's river of fire The Queen singing Auld Lang Syne The London Eye

The threat of a terrorist outrage at the Millennium Dome on New Year's Eve left Sir Paul Condon facing the biggest decision of his seven years as the Metropolitan police commissioner it emerged yesterday. Two hours before midnight on Friday, Sir Paul was briefed about a warning that a bomb had been planted in the dome. It differed from other hoaxes in the run up to the new year because a code word was used. But the word was not familiar to anti-terrorist officers, leaving them fairly convinced that it was a bluff. MI5 confirmed to the Met's assistant commissioner, Ian Johnston, who was in charge of policing on the night, that there was no intelligence to suggest groups opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process had planted a device. Mr Johnston's assessment was that the celebrations should go ahead; the dome had been searched and security on site was tight. Sir Paul supported Mr Johnston's judgment. There were plans for evacuating the dome, but it would have been logistically difficult and abandoning the showpiece of the nation's celebrations would have been a complete humiliation. Downing Street described reports that Tony Blair and the Queen had insisted "the show must go on" despite the threat as "rubbish". In an open letter, the home secretary Jack Straw congratulated the Met for dealing with the "series of bomb threats in London in the days leading up to the millennium and on the evening itself. Those threats turned out to be hoaxes, but each had to be taken seriously". A record 6,000 officers were on the streets on Friday. Crowds peaked at 3m, but there were just 99 arrests.

In prison the prospect of a new year always generates a giddy sense of excitement. Whereas Christmas serves only to intensify the solitariness of it all - families missed, friends preoccupied - the advent of a new year brings new hope, and with it new dreams. Everything good which never happened this year may just have a better chance of happening in the next one. And if nothing else it's another year over and we are still alive - still going strong. Well, most of us, anyway. The days blend together here, all very much the same, but on New Year's Eve we were unlocked late, at 8.30am, to give the officers a lie-in. Lunch was the same as usual - boiled potatoes, steak and kidney pie - but we had exercise in the morning, rather than working or staying in our cells. The sky was fantastically blue and the sun glinted off the razor wire as we walked about in circles. The highlight of the afternoon was a millennium quiz in the small dining room. It was won on the final question: 'Which Teletubby rides a scooter?' The answer, 'Po', secured five phone cards for Grede, the Open University student. Tolerance levels were high - lots of smiling, polite nods all around. Just before lock-up at 7pm the usual round of hand shakes and exchanges of goodwill took place. So, then, to the real excitement. We were locked up alone in our cells at 7pm. I listened to my radio, tuned to Radio 4, 'the prisoner's friend', just waiting for the pips. At ten minutes to midnight every prisoner in the country must have been standing at the door to his cell, blunt instrument in hand. I clutched a coffee tin. At midnight: bedlam. Chaos. Thunderous noise. Everyone banging on their doors together. It only lasts a couple of minutes, I suppose, but it seems to go on for an age. Someone somewhere was playing music - The 1812 Overture - though it was almost drowned out by the swearing, screaming and yowling. I think there were a couple of fires somewhere, as people burned their sheets. On my first new year inside - in the early 80s - I promised myself I wouldn't do the banging. It seemed silly. 'But everybody does it,' said the man who lived in the cell next door to mine as we shuffled along in the breakfast queue. 'It's traditional,' he said. I was in a London prison at the time: all steel gantries and prison officers who wore caps with peaks slashed low over noses. It was not an environment conducive to exuberant expression, unless of course you were being dragged kicking and screaming to the punishment block. And anyway, what if this chap was winding me up? After all we weren't exactly friends. Perhaps he was getting me at it - in the hope of providing himself with a smile at the appointed time. (Him: lying in bed chuckling to the chimes of Big Ben - Me: standing by my cell door waiting for 'the banging' to start, foolishly poised to join in.) By 9 o'clock I was in bed. Sleep, dreams, respite - and then suddenly, noise - lots of noise. My eyes opened wide and stared into the darkness. I pressed the light button at the side of my watch. Twelve midnight. I threw back the bed covers and ran to the door. Pressing my ear to the cold metal I listened in awe. The whole jail was vibrating as cell doors were battered mercilessly by all manner of blunt instruments. The noise was rising to thunderous levels as men by the score joined in. With my heart pounding I rummaged blindly in a locker drawer, until my hand grasped a tin of pilchards. Within seconds I had launched my attack. Bang! Bang! Bang! Ignoring the shock to my hand and arm and using all my strength, I hammered harder. Bang! Bang! Bang! How good it felt. How liberating. How cathartic . A couple of minutes later, save for the sporadic rantings of the more seriously disturbed, it was all over. The following year I was allocated to a long-term jail where I was introduced to more exotic ways of seeing in the new year. Thus I discovered 'shrunken bread syndrome' - and its cause. Illicit homebrew. So much yeast was stolen from the kitchens during the weeks leading up to the end of the year that the bakers were only able to turn out feeble looking loaves barely half the normal size. 'Hooch parties' were all the rage in those days, and 'Hooch masters' paid handsomely for the yeast to make the alcohol. Up to 15 men at a time would squeeze into out-of-the-way cells and guzzle strange brews to their hearts content. No amount of booze could diminish the ritual door banging at midnight however. New Year's Eve 1993 was precarious. The prison officers took the 'Hooch spin' (annual universal cell search) particularly seriously that year, and confiscated 24 gallons of 'Felons' Finest' from one wing. Uproar followed. Eventually a delegation met with the wing governor and heatedly intimated that the wing might be destroyed if the booze was not returned forthwith. Clearly the message had been received, as when the wing was unlocked for evening association there in the corner of the games room, glistening with welcome, stood a wooden cart laden with every type of plastic container imaginable. The evening had been saved. (Of course cannabis users celebrated too, but their festivities tended to be rather on the quiet side, punctuated only by the odd giggling fit.) The authorities have tightened up since then however, and substance abuse of any kind is no longer tolerated. But since the mandatory drug testing programme was introduced in 1994, the use of hard drugs has escalated. (Hard drugs stay in the body's system for a shorter time and so present the smallest risk of a positive test.) Consequently, sitting in a darkened cell with a couple of cohorts sniffing burnt smack (heroin) from the foil of a sweet wrapper seems to have replaced hooch-fuelled singalongs and dope induced catatonia as the most popular method of finding release from the pain of imprisonment these days. But although some things may have changed, the end-of-year rituals remain the same. The same old resolutions are made: the gymnasium is always packed for the first week or so of the new year, but by the second week most aspiring athletes have returned to the safer state of lethargic apathy. Smokers who want to give up bravely fail to buy tobacco on purpose knowing that the prison shop is going to be closed for two weeks. This is good news to their unscrupulous chums who buy extra, knowing that after the first week they'll be able to sell roll-ups for double the normal price. It has to be said however: there seems to be no greater sense of excitement about the arrival of the year 2000 than there was about the arrival of 1999. The nation may be gripped by millennium fever but in here it's passed us by. People are disdainful of all the hype outside, resentful almost, as if it's been forced on them. On New Year's Day we had another late unlock at 9am, but when I came out five minutes later, there was no one around. People emerged slowly through out the morning. No sense of excitement. During morning exercise, I walked with Stu, who we call the Guru. We had towels draped over our heads to protect us from the cold and from a distance we probably looked like a couple of monks. I asked him: 'What d'you make of this new millennium then?'And he said: 'Millennium. What millennium?' It summed up the prevailing attitude in here. Still, a happy new year to you all. And OK, why not? I'll say it for the first time and the last: a happy new millennium to you all.

webTitle: Let there be light entertainment as world treads into the unknown

fields.bodyText: A couple of lines, forgotten for 60 years, have been on my mind lately. 'I said to a man who stood at the gate of the year 'Give me a light that I may tread safely into the unknown'.' I doubt if anyone but a couple of queens remembers it now. George VI said it during a Christmas broadcast in 1939. We had no idea if we would reach 1940 or, more immediately, if he would reach the end of his sentence, given as he was to prolonged silences struggling with a stammer. The quotation propelled an unpretentious poetess called Minnie Haskins blinking into the light. The gate of the year was a revolving door during the BBC's live coverage of the millennium around the world, described as the biggest and most ambitious programme ever made. Everyone on earth wanted light. Nelson Mandela, walking stiff-legged and set-faced, lit a candle in his old cell. Those with money to burn frightened the night with fireworks according to their temperament. Sydney showily. Paris elegantly. Moscow economically, having a more sinister use for gunpowder. Stonehaven swung great balls of fire. Those with no money at all summoned the sun with song and dance. John Simpson, seasick and out of sync, had clearly had a bumpy five days on a tramp steamer reaching Millennium Island, the rising sun's first port of call. Only coconut crabs live there so both celebrants and TV crew had to be bussed in. One singer died on the boat and had to be briskly buried on an offshore island. The survivors refreshed themselves with a magic potion. It had a visibly cheering effect. Substantially built dancers in stout, cotton bras greeted the sun as, he translated, a young woman greets her lover. Their faces shone gold like buttered crumpets. This is Millennium Island's swan song: it is drowning from global warming. I live opposite the Millennium Dome. One day it appeared like a jellyfish washed up on the shore but recently, to my surprise, it has taken to palpitating at night, freckled with shifting spots, flushing like an octopus, which communicates with colour. The sense of a deep sea creature, defined only by light, is very strong. Professor Quatermass would have been interested. The Queen sailed down the river in the kind of boat that often passes at night, throbbing with music. As she approached, something happened which neither the BBC nor Sky seemed to notice. The Dome was clearly all of a flutter. Agitatedly, it changed its spots from orange to blue to green and, finally, flushed perfectly purple. The higher row of lights on its crown are always red but the lower row seem to flash emotion. As the Queen arrived, they threw beams of light upwards then, visibly in a tizzy, spun round repeatedly. One of the entertaining aspects of monarchy is that this is exactly how even the most self-assured react on meeting the Queen. When PG Wodehouse heard the first American jazz, he said he heard the 20th century. As you watched the samba spectacular in the Dome, you seemed to hear the 21st. After the show, a reporter stopped one dancer in skin-tight lycra saying 'Where are you from?' 'Harlesden' it replied and whirled away. In the heart of Greenwich is the church of St Alphege, Archbishop of Canterbury around the last millennium and the world's worst public speaker. Alphege was captured by Vikings, who celebrated with a feast in Greenwich. Candid to a fault, he rose to reproach them for drunkeness, using the wrong fork and various other failings of character. They beat him to death on the meridian line with bones. Some say stones. I like bones. The audience at the Dome, while not exactly bloodstained, were plied with Tesco champagne. The present archbishop kept it very brief and conciliatory. The mike caught his sotto voce advice to the children with him 'Wave to them!' In Sydney food stores farsightedly opened to help mop up the Fosters. In Britain, as no shops were open, legal commercials fervently appealed for clients who had, as they put it, tripped or fallen. I draw this to the attention of the three blokes who fell off London Bridge. The revolving door of the year reached an illuminated Hollywood sign (I am very worried about 20th Century Fox. What can we call it now?) and, last of all, Samoa, down to its last grass skirt, invoking the dawn in dance. The Samoan national anthem, according to Peter Ustinov, goes 'Well done, Samoa! Well done, Samoa!! Well done!!!'

webTitle: River of fire that fizzled out

fields.bodyText: It was billed as a "river of fire", a piece of pyrotechnic wizardry that would create the illusion of water turning to fire in a wall of flame advancing at the speed of the earth's rotation from Tower Bridge to Vauxhall. In the event, it just looked just like what it was - a load of rockets being let off from a dozen or so barges. It was no less spectacular for that - the 20-minute display enthralled the million or so people jammed along the banks of the Thames, and the millions more who saw it from other vantage points around London. It was the biggest firework display in British history - and people seemed to like it. Yesterday, the event's organisers, Big Time, were putting a positive gloss on things with a statement from which they would not budge: "The 39 tonnes of fireworks on 16 barges produced a fantastic 20 minute display." True enough: but what about that picture which accompanied the event's launch showing the Thames bathed in flames ... The theory went something like this. The explosives were packed onto barges 100 and 250 metres apart. A computer on the shore would send radio cues to the two operators on each barge, who would trigger detonations at an average time interval of 0.675 seconds. Each signal would send hundreds of fireworks into the air in a fan shape, appearing in the words of the organisers "as an advancing river of fire going upstream at 650 mph". The river of fire effect would be achieved, it was said, "because the fireworks ascend at different angles from the barges, [so] the detonations will take place at different distances from their launch positions". The reality was somewhat different. If you were standing on the Embankment in front of one barge, for instance, all you would have seen were the fireworks from that one, and a few on either side. Perhaps London's problem was quality of location: Sydney lit up the harbour bridge; Edinburgh had the unmatched backdrop of the castle; Paris the Eiffel Tower. Nowhere in London is there one location which could serve a similar purpose.

India and Pakistan began the new millennium in ill-temper as Delhi accused Islamabad of being behind the Christmas hijacking of an Indian plane. Atal Behari Vajpayee, the Indian prime minister, said: "All the information now available with the government about the hijack and the subsequent developments makes it clear that it was an integral part of the Pakistan-backed campaign of terrorism." An explosion in a busy vegetable market in the heart of Indian-ruled Kashmir that killed 15 people only stoked Indian anger at Pakistan. Indian officials said the target for the crude landmine was two vehicles carrying security officials who had come to shop for vegetables in Srinagar, summer capital of India's state of Jammu and Kashmir. The state has been wracked by separatist violence from Kashmiri militants seeking independence or close union with Pakistan. India has accused Pakistan of lending military support to the militants, including in the clashes of last summer that led to sustained artillery duels, aerial dogfights that brought the two rivals to the brink of war. Kashmir already has been the source of two of the three wars between India and Pakistan. The Christmas hijack of an Indian plane by Kashmiri militants now threatens to inflame relations between Delhi and Islamabad. The Indian government was criticised at the weekend for releasing three Kashmiri extremists from jail in exchange for the freeing of the 154 hostages aboard the Indian Airlines plane. Critics say the move will embolden guerrillas in Kashmir, India's only Muslim-majority state. In today's explosion, two security men were among those killed, who were mostly vegetable sellers. The vehicles were severely damaged. "It was a loud explosion and next I heard cries, the dead and wounded were all around. This is the most horrible moment of my life," said Joginder Singh, an Indian paramilitary soldier. The landmine exploded in Batmaloo suburb around 10:30 am local time, three days after a week-long hijack crisis which had its roots in the Kashmiri conflict. Separatist guerrillas launched a rebellion against Indian rule in the heart of the bitterly disputed Kashmir valley in January 1990. More than 25,000 people have been killed in the revolt, although Indian officials said last year that militancy had been contained. The latest flare-up in the sub-continent marks the first foreign policy test for Pakistan's new military regime, led by General Pervez Musharraf, who seized power last October from prime minister Nawaz Sharif. General Musharraf is believed to be the mastermind behind last summer's infiltration of Pakistani troops into Kashmir that triggered last summer's hostilities. He seized power after Mr Sharif was forced into a humiliating climbdown by the US and withdrew Pakistani forces from Kashmir. Observer There will always be winners and losers in the stock market. But the degree to which the gap between climbers and fallers has opened up over the past 12 months is unprecedented. A handful of stock market stars saw their price soar but the share prices of most companies actually went down... for virtually all of 1999, the majority of share prices were lower than they had been at the start of the year. Sunday Telegraph Don Cruickshank, the government's banking watchdog, intends to call for sweeping powers to make it easier for people to change their bank accounts. Bankers say that Cruickshank has been quizzing them on why people move their current accounts so rarely, even though many are unhappy with the service they receive. He is thought to believe that banks intentionally make it awkward to close one account and open another, limiting competition in the industry. BT and Vodafone are preparing to take control of Airtel, the £15bn Spanish mobile phone operator in which both British groups have stakes. The two are expected to increase their holdings to at least 30% each with the remainder held by Spanish companies. Britain's leading hospital software group is preparing to float this year, valued at up to £100m. iSOFT, a management buy-out from accountants KPMG in 1998 is in talks with financial advisers and is considering floating this summer. Sunday Times French electronics group Thomson-CSF is poised to table a bid for Racal Electronics. The offer is likely to value the group, including its planned £500m special dividend, at about £2bn. Thomson is expected to list its shares in London after the acquisition. French industry experts said last week that the deal was close to being finalised but had not yet been signed off. Increasing interest rates in Europe and America will cast a shadow over markets but they will not prevent 2000 being a year of strong growth. With the Bank of England's monetary policy committee meeting on January 12/13, the first significant rate rise of the year could come in Britain, though majority City opinion is that the committee will not increase the base rate from its present 5.5% until next month when clearer economic evidence becomes available. Sunday Business Rolls-Royce is understood to be studying plans drawn up by investment bankers for an attempt at a merger with rival aerospace engine maker Pratt & Whitney. The two companies held tentative talks five years ago but those came to nothing because the Rolls chairman, Sir Ralph Robins, insisted on retaining a majority interest in the proposed new group. Since then, however, strong market share gains by Rolls' successful Trent engines have convinced bankers that a deal could now be possible with the British company taking a dominant role. Notwithstanding the first 24 hours of the new year having passed with hardly any sign of the millennium bug, government ministers including Margaret Beckett urged caution, expressing fears that it might be lying dormant in computers, ready to strike as Britain returns to work this week. Mail on Sunday The stock market is expected to reach a record high this week amid growing optimism that the millennium bug has been licked and company profits will flourish in 2000. But the surge in share prices on both sides of the Atlantic could be short lived with economists predicting rate rises in the US, Britain and Germany - home of the European central bank - before the spring. IoS The Halifax predicts that the soaring house prices of recent months will ease this year as interest rate rises and the phasing out of mortgage interest relief at source damp any dangerous boom in prices. Of all the moving articles we have run on the four charities selected this year for the Guardian Christmas Appeal, none produced more response than our social services correspondent's account of a typical meeting of a grants panel of the Family Welfare Association (FWA). Many of our readers found it hard to believe that on the brink of the 21st century, ordinary people in one of the world's richest societies, were still petitioning a charity in their hundreds for such basic needs as putting shoes on the feet of their children, blankets on their beds and a cooker in their kitchen. As our correspondent noted, 'any passing thought that this is somehow outdated paternalism, demeaning for all involved, is swept aside by the sheer scale of the need and distress'. A civilised society should not be allowing this to happen. A progressive government, publicly committed to ending child poverty, should long ago have abolished the social fund's loan scheme, introduced by the Tories, and restored the old grant system. But Labour still has not moved, even though it opposed the loans in opposition. That is why the FWA remains such a crucial charity and needs your support. The other three are equally worthy of support: The Fairtrade Foundation, helping third world farmers get a better deal for their produce; Ockenden International, promoting self-reliance for refugees and displaced people; and Friends for Young Deaf People, promoting a partnership between deaf and hearing people. There are only two days left to call 0990 199 515. Please ring.

A British man held in an Indian jail over his alleged involvement in the kidnapping of three British tourists in India in 1994 was one of three men freed in return for the release of more than 155 hostages on board the hijacked Indian Airlines jet. Omar Sayyed Sheikh, a former student at the London School of Economics and a member of Harkat-ul-Ansar, a Pakistan-based Islamic fundamentalist organisation, was arrested in India in 1994 over the kidnapping of the three Britons. Last Friday he was released from jail in Ghaziabad, where he had been awaiting trial on the kidnapping charges. He is free to return to Britain if he chooses. Although the whereabouts of Sheikh and the other two prisoners is unknown, Pakistani officials deny claims that they and the five hijackers have crossed its borders. A spokesman for the foreign office said: "As a full British national he has every right to return [to Britain]. He has not been convicted of any offence, and we would provide normal consular assistance to help repatriate him." The crisis ended after Indian government officials negotiating with the hijackers acceded to demands to hand over three political prisoners held in India in exchange for the passengers. The sister of a hostage on the hijacked plane yesterday described his ordeal. Speaking from her Birmingham home, Kamaljeet Rehal told of her family's relief that her brother's experience was now over. Mrs Rehal knew on Saturday that her brother, 31, a community worker, was safe and spoke to him, but it was only yesterday that she found out how the incident had affected him psychologically. The family is still wary of naming the relative, who was returning from a business trip when the hijack occurred, for fear of repercussions.

Elliot Richardson commented in 1974 that, at the age of 54, he felt like a walking anticlimax. It was a strange confession from a man whose ancestors were probably waiting on shore to greet the Mayflower and who had compelled even Henry Kissinger to pay him the grudging tribute: 'He's as smart as I am.' Richardson's wry comment referred to the stunning impact he had made the previous year when he resigned as President Nixon's attorney general, a seismic political gesture which ensured Nixon's departure from the White House. It has never been clear if Richardson's appointment was a calculated gamble by Nixon to give his scandal-ridden administration an air of respectability or whether the president ludicrously misjudged the man he had chosen. Richardson, who has died aged 79, took over the justice department at the height of the senate investigation into the Watergate break-in. The acting director of the FBI, Patrick Gray, had already fallen on his sword for his part in the White House cover-up. Then, on April 30 1973, the president sacked his two principal aides, John Erlichman and Bob Haldeman, and his White House counsel, John Dean. He also accepted that Richard Kleindienst, the attorney general, had been stained by the scandal and must go. Within days, Kleindienst's replacement, Richardson, had decided to get to the bottom of the administration's involvement in this murky affair by selecting Archibald Cox as special prosecutor, asking him to review 'all the documentary evidence available from any source, to which he will have full access'. Unknown outside the administration at the time, the new attorney general was also confronted with unmistakable evidence that vice-president Spiro Agnew had been taking bribes for years. As Watergate erupted around him, much of the rest of his working day (often 14 hours) was spent trying to sort out the vice-presidential mess. Eventually, he persuaded Agnew not only that he must resign, but that he should accept a conviction for income tax evasion and a fine of $10,000. Richardson said later he thought this the quickest and cheapest solution, but it did not help his relations with the president. Nixon simply refused to see this key member of his cabinet. At one stage, Richardson joked privately that he might soon write a book called Situation Wanted. Matters swiftly came to a head when Alexander Butterfield revealed to senate investigators that President Nixon's Oval Office conversations had been secretly taped for years. The special prosecutor's demand to hear nine of the crucial tapes was rejected by Nixon, on the grounds of executive privilege. The White House offered to summarise the material. Cox stood firm and, on October 20, 1973, Nixon ordered Richardson to sack him and close down the special prosecutor's office. In a tense half-hour confrontation in the Oval Office (with reports flooding in of Israel's penetration into Egypt in the closing stages of the Yom Kippur war) Richardson told the president he had promised Cox full access to all the evidence. He could not obey the president's instruction and would consequently resign. 'Let it be on your head,' said Nixon. 'I'm sorry you can't put the nation's interests above your own concerns.' 'I'd like to feel,' Richardson responded icily, 'that what I'm doing is in the national interest.' Richardson's deputy, William Ruckelshaus, was then told to carry out the order. He also refused and resigned. Finally Robert Bork, the solicitor general, formally dismissed Cox, an act which an infuriated senate later avenged by refusing Bork a seat on the supreme court. Alexander Haig, the White House chief of staff, described what followed as 'the days of the firestorm'. Within 48 hours, 150,000 protest telegrams had been delivered to the White House: eventually they totalled 450,000. The heads of 17 leading colleges of law signed a petition calling for Nixon's impeachment. The press was overwhelmingly hostile and the end of Nixon's presidency was in sight. The man who tipped the balance was the polar opposite of the wheeling-dealing president. Richardson was born into one of those elite Boston families whose forebears settled New England in the 17th century. Many of his ancestors were doctors, but he opted for law because medicine was too predictable. His period at Harvard was interrupted by the war; he was one of the first to land in Normandy on D-Day. Post-war graduation with first-class honours got him a clerkship with the supreme court justice Felix Frankfurter and he moved steadily through the politico-legal landscape of US state and local government. In 1969, Nixon assigned him to the state department, where he helped keep Henry Kissinger and William Rogers from one another's throats. From there he became secretary of health and welfare, a thankless job in which he helped defuse both school desegregation and welfare reform. With this record behind him he was moved to the bureaucratic nightmare facing the secretary of defence; it was not his most glorious hour. As a smooth presenter of even a dodgy brief, he was regularly fielded by the White House to justify its illegal bombing of Cambodia to an increasingly hostile congress. Under President Ford, he served briefly as US ambassador to London and then as commerce secretary: no one else has held as many as four US cabinet posts. His final period in government, which he described as the longest and most demanding, was as head of the US delegation to the UN law of the sea conference from 1977 to 1980. It was certainly fruitful: he was credited with writing most of the resulting treaty. Voters did not warm to his reserved manner when he sought the Republican nomination for the senate from Massachusetts in 1984, and he remained in private practice as a lawyer in Washington until 1992. His wife, Anne, died in July last year. He is survived by their daughter and two sons. Elliot Lee Richardson, lawyer and politician, born July 20 1920; died December 31 1999

The jazz, blues and rock violinist Don 'Sugarcane' Harris, who has died of pulmonary illness aged 61, played on four of Frank Zappa's albums, including Hot Rats and Weasels Ripped My Flesh; performed with Little Richard's band in the early 60s; and, with his lifelong friend, the pianist Dewey Terry, worked as Don & Dewey from the 50s on. He was also a pioneer in the amplification of the violin. As he put it, he 'took a cartridge off a record player, taped the crystal to the wood of my violin, attached a shielded wire and plugged it into an amp.'' He was born in Pasadena to carnival entertainers and, from the age of six, learned classical violin. At arts high school in Los Angeles, he met Terry and the pair founded the Squires doo-wop vocal group. They also wrote and sang rhythm & blues, as Don & Dewey. They recorded in the early 50s for the Los Angeles Spot and Shade labels, and were then signed by Art Rupe, owner of the Specialty label, for which Little Richard recorded. Between 1957-59, Don & Dewey made singles which often borrowed Little Richard-style rhythms. None was a big hit, although several were later covered by others: I'm Leaving It Up To You was a 1963 hit, which was revived in 1974 by Marie and Donnie Osmond, while the Searchers featured their novelty song. Farmer John. It was while touring with the Johnny Otis review in the late 50s that Harris got his 'Sugarcane' sobriquet, from Otis himself, in recognition of his reputation as a ladies' man. In 1963-64, while with Little Richard's band, Harris played bass as well as violin and featured on the hit Bama Lama Bama Loo. As a teenager, Frank Zappa had been transfixed by Don & Dewey's Soul Motion, which had been produced by Sonny Bono. So Zappa recruited Harris to provide a tough, improvisatory edge to four, mainly instrumental, albums. Harris also toured with and played on blues albums by John Mayall (Union Station) and Harvey Mandel (Choice Cuts). Harris's violin playing, said Mayall, had 'the same sort of vitality that an electric guitar has''. Harris's solo albums included Sugar Cane, which contained an affectionate classical parody, Funk And Wagner, and Fiddler On The Rock (1970) and New Violin Summit (1973) with fellow violinists Jean Luc Ponty and Michael Urbaniak. Harris made several successful European tours. He explained enthusiastic audience reaction there by saying that ''the violin is a very European instrument. Hearing it played so differently, it's a gas to them.' By 1975, reunited with Terry in LA, Don & Dewey were playing oldies' shows. Some attributed his career decline to drug problems and a disinclination to tour. Recordings became infrequent, though in the early 80s, he guested on a ska album with LA punk band Tupelo Chain Sex. According to Terry, he and Harris had recently made new recordings. Harris was divorced and leaves a daughter and two sons. Donald Bowman Harris, musician, born June 18 1938; died November 30 1999

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.bodyText: Who? The man responsible for making large numbers of men grow stubble, roll up the sleeves on their pastel-coloured suit jackets and stop wearing socks. Don's role as Sonny Crockett in Miami Vice ensured he was really, really big in the 80s, but he'd been acting since he was a child. Sadly, he is also well known for his marriages to Melanie Griffith, and his drug and alcohol problems - although he's now recovered from all these bad habits. The 90s has seen Johnson back on TV with his own show, Nash Bridges. The role: Vic, a sullen teenager. But then, you'd be sullen if you lived in the post-apocalyptic aftermath of World War IV, with only a telepathic dog to keep you out of trouble. Best Line: When the dog, Blood, tries to explain that there is a place where people can still farm and not everything is polluted, Vic says: 'Yeah, and they also have a great crop of clothes and guns and gorgeous chicks.' Cringe factor: Low. As a former child star, Johnson is pretty much above embarrassment. And he did go on to star in Harley Davidson And The Marlboro Man with Mickey Rourke, so he obviously has no shame. Other wannabes: Director LQ Jones (real name Justus McQueen), who plays 'man in porno film' in this movie, later starred in Casino and The Mask of Zorro, among others. Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin describes it as a 'cult black comedy' but warns that it 'is definitely not a kiddie movie, despite its title'. Also not starring in: An episode of Kung Fu in 1972, and as Harley McKay in 1975's Return To Macon County. A Boy And His Dog, Carlton Cinema, Monday January 3, 11.0pm.

webTitle: Race to investigate war crimes suspect

fields.bodyText: Specialists from Scotland Yard's disbanded war crimes unit have been drafted in to make a rush assessment of whether a Latvian accused of involvement in the murder of hundreds of Jews during the second world war can be arrested and prosecuted in the UK, the Guardian has learned. Investigators who led the prosecution of Anthony Sawoniuk at the Old Bailey last April have been briefed about Konrad Kalejs, who arrived in Britain last summer and is said by Nazi hunters to be one of the most wanted war criminals still at large. Home office sources admitted yesterday it would be `a race against time'. There is nothing to stop Mr Kalejs, 86, leaving Britain before a proper assessment is made. The UK has not been asked to arrest and extradite him by another country, as in the case of the former Chilean leader Augusto Pinochet. And Mr Kalejs has not committed an offence since his arrival in Britain. But with pressure mounting from British and international Jewish groups, specialists from the war crimes unit have reconvened. `Although the unit has been officially disbanded, the expertise remains,' said a home office source. `These cases can take a long time. The officers will consider whether there is enough evidence to make an arrest on the basis of the information they have. If another country requested his arrest then it would be considered in the usual way.' Officers are expected to interview Mr Kalejs within days. In an interview with the Mail on Sunday yesterday, he denied being a war criminal and said he wanted to `leave this country as soon as I can'. He added: `I have learned my lesson. The police cannot hold me. I have been hounded round the world for 15 years, and now I want to be left alone. There's no peace for me here now.' Mr Kalejs arrived in Britain from Australia six months ago and is living in Catthorpe Manor, a retirement home on the Leicestershire/Warwickshire border run by a welfare fund for Britain's Latvian community of 8,000. He checked in under a false name with his common law wife, Austra Kalnins, but she has since returned to Australia. According to the US justice department, Mr Kalejs was joint second in command of the arajs kommandos, a Latvian secret police unit that worked with the Nazis in murdering 30,000 people, mainly Jews. Mr Kalejs, who has held an Australian passport since 1957, is reported to believe that returning to Australia is his best chance of escaping prosecution. In yesterday's interview, he claimed that the allegations of war atrocities were the work of `liars and storytellers'. He said he had been conscripted into the Red Army in 1940 and then deserted. After returning to Riga to study, he had been called up to the Latvian auxiliary security police in 1942 but was too ill to serve. But documents from the Russians and Germans show he joined the arajs kommandos and was a company commander and lieutenant from July 1941 to mid-1944. Efraim Zuroff, director of the Simon Wiesenthal centre, said Mr Kalejs must not be allowed to return to Australia, where there was `no political will to put Nazi criminals on trial'. He urged the home secretary, Jack Straw, `to put him on trial or at least hold him long enough so Latvia can put him on trial.' Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said yesterday: `The Latvian government must be chased to make a decision about bringing extradition proceedings. `Allowing this man to leave Britain without the chance of facing the most serious charges against him would be an international tragedy and scandal. Any steps that can be taken by the Leicestershire police and the Met police must be taken as a matter of urgency.'

webTitle: Jack Straw orders deportation of suspected Nazi war criminal

fields.bodyText: Home secretary Jack Straw today ordered Konrad Kalejs to leave Britain amid a growing public clamour for the government to throw out the suspected Nazi war criminal. Mr Straw's deportation notice followed an investigation into how Kalejs who was known by Scotland Yard to be suspected of murdering thousands of Jews was allowed into Britain. Kalejs indicated at the weekend that he had seen the writing on the wall. "I am leaving this country as soon as I can," Kalejs told the Mail On Sunday before the deportation notice was officially served on him, "I have learned my lesson. The police cannot hold me," he said. The Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem, which tracks down Nazi war criminals and traced Kalejs to Britain, immediately urged the British government to act. "We are calling for the British to arrest (Kalejs) and put him on trial for war crimes unless there is an extradition request from Latvia," the centre's director, Efraim Zuroff, said. "Britain should view this as an opportunity to achieve justice rather then as a problem that was thrust in their lap." The home office came under heavy criticism since it emerged that Kalejs, an 86-year-old Australian citizen who has previously been deported from Canada and the United States, has been living in a retirement home in Lutterworth, Leicestershire. In a further embarrassment to Mr Straw, the US department of justice told the Guardian it had shared information about Kalejs with the Metropolitan police, while the Yard's now disbanded war crimes unit was investigating another war crimes suspect. Like Kalejs, Harijs Svikeris was also believed to have been part of the notorious Arajs Kommando unit, which was involved in the murder of at least 30,000 people, mainly Jews. Kalejs was identified in his Canadian deportation judgment as a war criminal by Svikeris. The two men are believed to have been joint second in command of the unit. Svikeris, who lived in Milton Keynes, died before he could be prosecuted. A department of justice spokesman said: "We shared a great deal of our Kalejs material with Scotland Yard for their use in the Svikeris investigation." After home office officials admitted they could do nothing to prevent Kalejs leaving Britain, it was feared that he would flee before he could be arrested. He arrived in Britain in July on an Australian passport. Under immigration regulations Kalejs is due to leave on January 6. Australia has said it would take Kalejs back. British forces which spearheaded last summer's occupation of Kosovo were bedevilled - and could have been placed in mortal danger - by deficient weapons and equipment and scrambled lines of communication. Two reports by front-line commanders suggest that had the invasion been resisted, there could have been horrendous casualties. This is serious, as well as eye-catching. But we should not be too carried away. The reports, carefully leaked to the BBC Today programme this morning, carry a heavy whiff of crude Ministry of Defence budget politicking. What is more, both were very deliberately intended to highlight the shortcomings of the operation, as an aid to future planning. All the same, the reports reveal some damning flaws in the Kosovo campaign. The airborne forces at the sharp end of the expedition had guns which did not work properly, and had to borrow weapons from other units. They lacked night vision equipment and could not operate properly after dark. The chain of command was confused, and orders were routinely countermanded. The soldiers were inadequately briefed about their duties and legal responsibilities once they had established control of the battered province. At one level, this is confirmation that the military machine remains a blunt and blundering instrument. Forget all the hype about surgical precision, perfect discipline and split-second timing: all armies tend to make up their operations as they go along. We should remember too that the Kosovo operation was a more than usually ad hoc affair, dictated less by military considerations than by the squalid dither and confusion of Nato's political masters. Now, where once Belgrade's federal army had overseen the brutal persecution of Albanians, Nato's woefully ill-equipped and prepared troops have watched over the expulsion of 90% of the province's Serbs. The ethnic cleansing of Kosovo is all but complete. In that godawful context, the cockups of the actual invasion are a footnote. But they do raise interesting and urgent issues for military planners and analysts and, more important, will fuel the debate about defence funding. Equipping and training a modern army is screamingly expensive (ditto, with knobs on, for modern air and naval forces). The reports from Kosovo highlight just how close to the bone successive defence budget cuts have sliced. That is precisely why the reports have been leaked. Advances in military technology have added exponentially to defence costs. In the post-Cold War world, priorities and objectives are ever harder to define. It remains true that war is too important a business to be left to generals. But Kosovo, more than any other recent conflict, strongly suggests that politicians are dangerous people to be put in charge of armies. Related link: Special report The last Peanuts The most endearing and successful comic strip of all time appears for the last time in daily newspapers today. Charles Schultz, the creator of Peanuts, has drawn his last Snoopy, Charlie Brown,and Lucy. The strip first appeared in October 1950. Since then, Schultz has become an extraordinary one-man industry. His strip appears in 2600 newspapers read by more than 350m people daily, in 75 countries. Now 77, he is suffering from colon cancer, and has laid down his pen.There will be no more Peanuts, for Schultz's contract stipulates that no other artist can take over his gallery of loveably goofy characters. But at least there is a half-century of re-runs available, most of them inimitably timeless. Related links: Peanuts official site US National Cartoonists Society

webTitle: England rely on their elders and betters

fields.bodyText: Any of us can make a New Year resolution and fail to live up to it, but it takes an England cricket team to end the old year in resolute fashion and start the new one by falling apart. To lose one batsman caught at third man and another to the hook trap may be considered a misfortune. To lose two in each of these ways looks like something worse than carelessness. And as for Chris Adams ... Yesterday lunchtime, the spread-betting people thought England were heading for 420. That's how good a toss it was to win, how good a pitch, and how good a start by Atherton and Butcher. Twenty-four hours later, those two must have wondered why they had bothered, as 213 for 3 turned to 258 all out. The other day a statistician revealed that England no longer had the worst tail in the world. Is he quite sure? Nasser Hussain was one of the two frontline batsmen who didn't get out to an awful shot - the other, naturally, was the very reverend Michael Vaughan. But Hussain was to blame in a deeper sense. In yesterday's Sunday Telegraph, Scyld Berry conducted a revealing round-table discussion between Hussain, Atherton, Barry Richards and Graeme Pollock, in which Hussain said that the reason the selectors chose the present batting line-up was that something had had to be done about England's top six. In fact, both last summer and in other recent series, England's top six had exactly matched that of their opponents. The weakness in the batting was the bottom five. The dropping of Mark Ramprakashæwas based on a fallacy. Hussain thought it would be good for team spirit to take several beginners, and he has clearly been proved right. But he has paid a heavy price in terms of runs and wickets. In effect, he has been playing with half a team. England have made seven big individual scores, ranging from Hussain's stonewall 146 to Atherton's sparkling 71 (interesting how those two have swapped stereotypes), and every one has come from the three old stagers. In 18 innings, Hussain, Atherton and Stewart have made 776 runs at an average of 48, which is all you would have expected and a little more, especially given the way they began. It's worth looking at their scores, in chronological order: 0, 0, 0; 0, 16, 86; 108, 82, 15; 3, 70*, 28; 1, 146*, 95; 71, 15, 40. Leaving aside Mark Butcher, who is neither one thing nor the other (like his footwork a lot of the time), the rest of the batting consists of three novices, Vaughan (or his understudy, Darren Maddy), Chris Adams and Andy Flintoff. They have also played 18 innings, which look like this 33, 16, 38; 5, 1, 36; 21, 25, 42; 29, 1, 12; 24, 19, 5; 42, 10, 22. Total 381 runs - half as many as their elders and betters - at an average of 21. This too is more or less what you would have expected. The striking thing is the number of starts the young ones have made: ten times out of 18, they have reached 20, or Done the Hard Part as the coaches say. Hussain, Atherton and Stewart have managed it just nine times, but only Stewart (twice) has failed to capitalise, and he has the excuse that he is having to keep wicket. This is not to condemn Vaughan, Adams and Flintoff out of hand. Vaughan's defence is impressive, and so is Flintoff's hitting, though for a man who is fond of a pint he is easily intoxicated by his own strength. This time 10 years ago, England took a bunch of novice batsmen to the West Indies. Team spirit flowed, the runs didn't, and two promising players kept getting out between 20 and 45. Alec Stewart and Nasser Hussain made it in the end, and so should Vaughan and Flintoff. But it will be a lot easier for them if they play in a side that wins the odd Test match. Having Adams there with them, rather than Ramprakash, makes that highly improbable. Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. He was voted Editor of the Year in the special-interest category of the recent British Society of Magazine Editors awards.

webTitle: British Kosovo troops hampered by failed guns, 'fractured' command and few powers

fields.bodyText: Nato's advance into Kosovo was blighted by serious equipment failings experienced by British troop units, it is reported today. According to documents leaked to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, supposedly secure radios could be listened into by the Serbs. Guns issued to British paratroopers did not work properly, and some had to borrow weapons from other units, the documents, drawn up by senior British commanders, suggested. Troops could not work properly after dark because they lacked sufficient quantities of night vision equipment. And one paratrooper unit had to let a suspected war criminal go free because they lacked a legal basis on which to detain him. The BBC said that the leaked documents suggested that the British forces were ill-prepared for an opposed invasion. It quoted one of the documents as saying: "It is the view of this headquarters that had the situation on 12th June (the day of Nato's advance) been anything less than benign, there would have been command, control and communication difficulties which could not have been resolved by K-For headquarters." One section highlighted the unreliability of the paratroopers' guns. "During both blank and live training for Kosovo the light support weapon proved to be both unreliable and insufficiently robust." On communications, the document stressed: "Communications are essential for the success and survival of light forces. We were fortunate that an inadequate system was not put to the test." The Ministry of Defence issued a statement in response to the BBC's report. The MoD said that Britain and its allies were well prepared to launch a land campaign in Kosovo. And it was confident that this would have proved successful, had it been necessary to commence such a campaign. The documents displayed concerns among the military about their inability to detain war crimes suspects. "There was much discussion about law, but little application of justice. Meanwhile the Albanian community in particular meted out violence on Serbs, sure in the knowledge that we were impotent to stop them." Another section in one of the documents suggested that the headquarters of K-For commander General Sir Mike Jackson was too distant from troops on the ground, leading to "confused and fractured" command. "Soldiers were operating in something of a vacuum which lasted for several days. There were constantly changing orders and confusion, with a potentially damaging effect on morale. This erodes confidence and may, in extremis, place individual soldiers in an invidious position." Bruce George, the Labour MP for Walsall South who chairs the Commons select committee on defence, said he wanted to see action taken on the shortcomings suggested by the leaked documents. "The documents ... have raised very interesting points. The defence committee has conducted substantive inquiries after every war, and we have already begun a very serious inquiry into the lessons to be derived from the war in Kosovo," said Mr George. "The defence committee produced a report on the Strategic Defence Review and we reached the conclusion that if the Government wished to achieve its objectives, politically and militarily, then defence expenditure would have to rise beyond the rather miserable level to which it has sunk over the last 15 years. Mr George said he was disturbed about the military's inability to detain war crime suspects. "This is not a military failure, it is a political inadequacy in which people who were undertaking peace keeping were in fact given inadequate legal tools," he said. A spokesman for the Ministry of Defence said the equipment failings detailed in the reports would not have damaged the success of any land campaign in Kosovo. The two reports, prepared by a lieutenant colonel and a brigadier, were designed to be as "critical as possible" of the armed forces' performance in the campaign, he added. They would form part of a larger review of the military action in Kosovo which will be published later this year. "We always, after a campaign such as Kosovo, review the events as soon as possible and as critically as possible," said the MoD spokesman. "These reports are two of many such reports. "They will form part of a balanced overall picture which we will be making public when we publish a report on the campaign later this year." He added: "With our 18 allies in Nato we prepared for a land campaign and were confident that this would have been successfully executed, had it been necessary. Shadow Defence Secretary Iain Duncan Smith called for a wide-ranging inquiry into the military's problems during the Kosovo conflict. Mr Duncan Smith said: "It's very, very worrying obviously, and it's very worrying that we have to get this via a leaked report. "The most important thing is that this was pretty much perhaps as good as it will get, because this was done on the previous budget." Former Liberal Democrat leader and Balkans expert Paddy Ashdown said the leaked documents suggested serious problems, but added that they contained the kind of complaints frequently voiced following a conflict. "Well it's undoubtedly very serious and I hope it will be taken seriously. But ... I don't think I can ever remember a single campaign ... in which there were not afterwards natural and proper complaints by frontline soldiers about the inadequacy of the equipment and the staff." "But it has to be put in its context. This was a highly successful operation which was brought off with great skill and courage," Mr Ashdown told the Today programme.

webTitle: Broken guns and old radios: standard issue to British soldiers

fields.bodyText: The British Army's chosen rifle is the troubled SA80, developed at the Royal Small Arms factory in Enfield. Launched to a fanfare of applause in 1985 as the modern weapon of choice for the Army, soldiers soon complained that the gun - developed at a cost of £384 million - had serious faults. In March last year, the Ministry of Defence scientists identified 'underlying problems' with the rifle. Soldiers in the Gulf complained that firing pins broke, sand jammed the mechanism, a faulty catch allowed the magazine to fall out, the trigger stuck and the bayonets fell off during training. It was even suspended from Nato's list of acceptable weapons and the faults discovered so far have cost over £24 million to rectify. And it was no good for left-handers. The news that British soldiers had problems using their radio units is also not new. Soldiers in Kosovo reportedly had to borrow cellular phones from reporters there as their own communications didn't work. Most British units use the obsolete Clansman radio, developed originally in the 1960s. Its signals were, according to the reports, regularly intercepted by the Serbs. And there is no immediate solution in site: it was announced last month that, after many delays, the new £2.2 billion Bowman radio system will be delayed by two years, and is scheduled to enter service in 2004 - eight years late. But even that is not the end of the saga. Because Ministry of Defence rules mean that 'acceptance' of a product is defined as use by a brigade-sized part of the army, only around 2000 people could end up using the new equipment out of 102,000 serving soldiers. It's all part of what is becoming a fine tradition of army equipment problems. A National Audit Office report in 1988 found that the military's stocktaking process was hopelessly inefficient and that millions of pounds of equipment had gone missing. Soldiers in the Gulf also found that their Challenger tanks lacked vital spare parts.

webTitle: Russia's bombardment of Chechnya goes on

fields.bodyText: The Russian assault on the Chechen capital Grozny continued today, despite pressure from Germany to halt its campaign and rebel reports of mounting Russian casualties. "As long as this conflict continues it will cast a shadow over the relationship between Russia and Germany and the European Union," German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's foreign policy adviser, Michael Steiner, told German Radio. Chechen rebel spokesman Movladi Udugov claimed the Russians were suffering mounting casualties and had lost control of three villages southwest of Grozny. Moscow denied the report. Federal officials reported that Russian jets and artillery had bombed a small village in Chechnya's southern mountains, trying to block the path of retreating rebel forces. The strikes killed some 50 militants and wiped out two rebel bunkers, said Russian military spokesman major Alexander Diordiev. These death tolls could not be confirmed. During the Chechen campaign both sides have routinely exaggerated claims of losses inflicted on their opponents. RIA news agency reported today that some 80 more guerrillas had been killed in clashes around Vedeno, home base of rebel commander Shamil Basayev in the mountains south of Grozny. Only three Russian solders were killed, RIA said. Interfax news agency quoted military sources in Mozdok, Russia's main army base in the North Caucasus just outside Chechnya, as saying up to 35 rebel fighters had been killed in the latest clashes in and around Grozny. A spokeswoman for a body representing the mothers of Russian soldiers told Ekho Moskvy radio at least 1,000 federal troops had died and about 3,000 had been wounded during the military operation. The radio said the Russian defence ministry had put the number of federal troops killed until the end of November - roughly two months after the campaign started - at about 300. Acting president Vladimir Putin, propelled into the Kremlin by Boris Yeltsin's shock resignation last Friday, discussed the situation in the Russian-controlled parts of Chechnya today with Nikolai Koshman, Moscow's top representative in the war-racked province. Mr Putin wants to finish the Chechen war if possible before Russia's presidential election, set for March, which he is the favourite to win.
