The war is popular among Russians and forms the basis for the acting president's high opinion poll ratings.  A gunman has been shot dead in Beirut after firing grenades at the Russian embassy. It was believed the gunman was protesting against Russia's bombardment of Chechnya. One policeman was killed in the incident.

Cocaine, put on earth by God, perverted by nasties, rendered tedious by Channel 4. Construction workers, football hooligans, painters, decorators... the thought of cocaine-crazed white van man will bring shudders to Tunbridge Wells. No mention, however, of Freud's Cocaine Papers, Sherlock Holmes's bottle, or the Empire of the Incas, who looked upon the coca shrub as a living manifestation of divinity. Coming down from the transcendental 60s, sweet cousin cocaine whispered to me of dangerous glamour; rock gods had lines laid out on top of their amps and we all knew about Hollywood Babylon. Since then it has gone through the grim process of democratisation and become The People's Drug of the 90s. Housewives in Hampshire can now order what Tallulah Bankhead called the 'absolutely divine' from a man in the market. It's as commonplace as the mobile phones that make dealing it so easy. I suppose it's still fun, but it doesn't look like it from these programmes. Because no dealer in their right mind would go on screen and admit to possession with intent to supply Class A drugs, most interviews in Secrets And Lines (9pm, Thursday, Channel 4) are recreated by actors. Apparently the spawn of prohibition are doing very nicely, thank you, 'I could never live on the 300 quid you get for a 9-to-5 job, know what I mean?' Especially nauseating is 'high-end dealer' Johnny Mohair, played as a camp coloured man with a blond top knot, who grovels before the status of the people he sells to. 'I have a duty to respect my clients, and in return they respect me.' Who's he kidding? The token female dealer was a dodgy blonde who bore no resemblance to any of the chicks I knew who trekked up mountain pathways to bring back the best Bolivian flake. My Mate Charlie (9pm, Wednesday, Channel 4) deals with the up-tight white folk for whom a wrap of coke is a couple of phone calls away. Like Sue, looking strangely fit and tanned yet dead within, who blew her inheritance of £322,000 up her nostrils at a rate of 15 grams a day. When she'd licked the wrap and scratched at the floorboard for fallen fragments she would blow her nose and eat the tissue. 'My dealer was my only friend.' During his Thin White Duke ordeal David Bowie blew his nose and thought his brains had fallen out. He had mind enough left to know it was time to quit the Nietzschean fantasies. At least it had brought us some great music. What can 90s man Matt the Welder, on three grams a day, bring us from his less exotic nasal passages? 'Blobs of blood, and grisly bacon stuff.' His voice utters from a face of uncooked pastry, and he is so dedicated to the White Mischief that he says he won't stop until his nose falls off. A Fantastic Voyage - like journey up the inside of Matt's proboscis brought screams of terror from the younger viewers. Also in this trio of coke-fest programmes is Cocaine On The Brain (10pm, Wednesday, Channel 4), featuring bog-standard medical experts, and a young group of 'cocaine takers' who are studied during an evening's indulgence. In the late 19th century, Freud was berated for his advocacy of 'the third scourge of humanity', but his data on the effects of cocaine deserve mention as much as any thing because the person he experimented on was himself, and it's hard to improve on such methodology. 'Here we have someone who is high,' says a psychopharmacologist, indicating a woolly-hatted youth. A girl sitting by a fibre-optic light shares her inner secrets: 'You can get into things, I feel so focused... let's have another line.' The screen becomes a Tron-like playground for diagrams of neurotransmitters, pleasure zones and computer-animated arrows of activated dopamine raging round the brain. Pavlovian psycho-stimulant surges are measured by men with clipboards, inevitably followed by words of warning from the man in a blue medical gown: vasoconstriction, blood clots, death... the usual price for substance abuse. In the 1880s Dr Fleischl, brilliant physician and friend of Freud, developed cocaine poisoning after taking a gram a day over a period of time and seeing white snakes creep over his skin. Why not tell us about the various substances used to cut today's coke with? Is it glucose, lactose, novocaine, Ajax? How can we obtain quality control? Was that real coke on the mirrors? If so, they were harsh lines. Explain the difference between pharmaceutical and rock, or what happens to your lungs if you smoke it (the rumour is it crystallises). My son tells me on the club scene it's mostly smoked because the loos are carefully watched for the joy powder brigade. I wonder anxiously what toxins are coursing round his bloodstream, I know I shouldn't, but I have to ask. He tells me not to worry, but he would, wouldn't he? Who listened in the death-trip 70s, when we were told it popped your brain cells and they never grew back? I was too busy pretending I was the coke-head heroine of Aleister Crowley's Diary Of A Drug Fiend 'Her eyes glittered, her lips twittered... She was the spirit of cocaine incarnate; cocaine made flesh.' In reality I was a mess, and left town thin and broke. Perhaps a few opium dens to chill out in wouldn't go amiss. From Channel 4's trawl through the coke snorting hoi-polloi there seems to be no other answer.

On BBC1's 6 O'Clock News, poor Huw Edwards still looks like someone sentenced to reading an autocue for an unspecified anti-Birtist crime. At 9 O'Clock on the same channel, Michael Buerk and Peter Sissons are said to be sulking, convinced their bulletin has been downgraded ever since the 'Six' was relaunched. On ITV at 6.30, Sir Trevor McDonald has yet to regain the authority which News At Ten gave him. And on Channel 5, a programme built around ITV defector Kirsty Young will now have to be reconstructed. Looking across the main terrestrial bulletins, the lone vibrant exception to this pattern of misery and resentment is Channel 4 News, which has already successfully introduced a Saturday edition and next Sunday (albeit in exchange for losing 30 minutes on Fridays) becomes a seven-day operation. After a year as presenter, reporter, debate referee and celebrity interviewer, anchorman Jon Snow is raring to go. 'I've always had a genuine passion to see a serious Sunday news programme, and I think other channels have missed a trick, that there's a real appetite for something that says, 'the weekend's ending, where are we, what's happened, what's going to happen?' On Saturday, you know, we're getting the best figures of the week, 1.6m heading out to 2m, and my feeling is we could get more. In fact, I'd be disappointed if we don't get 2m.' Jim Gray, lured away from Newsnight by Michael Jackson to edit and overhaul Channel 4 News, says that he soon found that the Saturday bulletin he introduced last year needed to 'rattle along' more than he expected, but is convinced the 'more reflective, more lateral' approach that he initially planned for Saturday will work on a Sunday. Among its other defining features, he adds, will be 'a strong international perspective, investigative stories given room to breathe, and long interviews at the top of the programme.' Asked if he still sees himself as the bolshy 'enemy within' at ITN, Snow laughingly replies, 'not with Jim Gray around - I'm no longer alone. I feel very much part of Channel 4. I feel rather less part of ITN, within which Channel 4 News is a very aberrant creature, but it's ITN who pay me and I haven't worked for anyone else, except briefly in radio. So it's an odd situation, a split-personality thing.' Does the fact that the same organisation is now making bulletins for ITV at 6.30pm and Channel 4 at 7pm cause problems? 'Not really. Because of the way technology has developed, we're able to extract material at the same time. And, anyway, we and ITV are actually rarely scrabbling over the same ground. I don't think, for instance, that we covered the death of Cilla Black's husband in any great depth, but they did it for three minutes.' This is said with dry humour, but his underlying point is serious. 'I mean, ITV's got out of the business of public service broadcasting. News At Ten was a public service. There's a great swathe of people in British society who don't have the time or inclination to watch news before 10pm, and they're entitled to a channel that provides it. By moving the news, ITV have forfeited all right to be called a public service broadcaster.' What's Snow's assessment of the 6.30 bulletin? 'Well, it's 'right for its market',' he replies, grinning broadly. The BBC fares no better, with Newsnight's 11pm Scottish opt-out slated as 'a complete disgrace. In fact, the whole way the BBC has responded to Scotland is very mealy-mouthed. If even Westminster can countenance devolving power, the BBC should certainly have a devolved a 'Scottish Six' news bulletin. The fact that they didn't shows really scared thinking.' Snow has been approached to defect 'from time to time, over the years', but says 'the BBC would have to change profoundly for it to be tempting. It's far better resourced than any of us have ever dreamt of, and it would be wonderful to have all those resources to play with. But on the other hand it would be awful to put up with the stale breath of the bureaucrats who would be peering over your shoulder. 'And they do: whenever you meet your BBC counterparts, there's always something burdened about them, they've always got a shoulder sagging - and on that shoulder is the heavy arm of those endless bureaucrats. Even in Jeremy Paxman's case, there's probably four or five layers of accountants and other sorts of creature above him, whereas there's only one person between me and the boss of Channel 4, and that's Jim Gray.' Adding to his enthusiasm for the channel is the way it has belatedly begun to exploit his talents by using him for what he calls 'extra-curricular' work, such as last Thursday's On the Line programme which was Snow's own idea. Alongside the day power was devolved to Northern Ireland - beginning at Seamus Heaney's house in Dublin, and ending at Stormont - and forays to Macedonia and Kosovo, one of his personal highlights of the year was travelling to Australia to chair a rumbustious pre-referendum debate on the monarchy. 'Fantastic! I thought I'd died and gone to heaven. If you said to somebody, 'go to a country about which people [here] know nothing and care less, find 80 people nobody here's ever heard of, put them in a studio and make a good programme', they'd think you were mad. But it was wonderful, and it raised issues that are relevant here because in Britain the monarchy is rarely discussed, it's the subject that dares not speak its name.' His interview with Monica Lewinsky is not among the high points he singles out, and he freely admits it was flawed: 'I asked some very fatuous questions, like 'did [Clinton] make you tingle?', which was probably not a very wise idea, but on the other hand nothing about interviewing Mikhail Gorbachev and Margaret Thatcher prepares you for interviewing a young woman who hasn't been found in bed with the President.' Did he fail to ask obvious questions because he was too diffident, as some women profile-writers suggested? 'I might be. It's a difficult problem. You never have to interview 24-year-old women in depth, basically. And as the depths had all sorts of Freudian connotations, I felt I was treading on very, very rocky ground and could have got into really serious trouble - so the fact that I emerged only criticised for not asking more specific questions was OK. 'I've often asked myself, 'should I have done a more aggressive, make-the-woman-cry interview?' Barbara Walters did her on the same day and her ambition, which she achieved, was simply to make her cry. But I thought [in my interview] the real Monica came across, perfectly nice and rather naive. And, after all, what's your service to the viewer? It's to share some real insight about who she is. But it would have been interesting to see the difference if Paxo had also intereviewed her.' Famously dubbed 'that pinko' by Denis Thatcher, Snow is unusual among news presenters in the candour of his opinions - about ITN and ITV, for example, or about whether working journalists should accept honours from No 10 (he declined one), but also about political issues. He needs no prompting to defend this openness: 'It's important to stop imagining that there is a human being who is neutral. I don't believe it. There ain't such a thing. What you have to be is fair, to let people state their case, and be aware that the whole way you interview them is shaped by your prejudices, where you're coming from.' Is John Humphrys penning regular columns for the Sunday Times a wholly good thing, then? 'He's a much more irascible and opinionated person than I am, but yes, I believe in an open society, and the more viewers know about what you really think, the more they can form an opinion as to what it is they're being given. 'This is probably dangerous territory, but I think it also helps to know how these people live in society. Then you know where they're coming from. There are plenty of presenters with fine stock-holding portfolios and reams of privately educated children, who also come from a particular perspective but don't show their hand.' Describing the movie Broadcast News as 'full of all kinds of truths' about TV journalism, Snow relishes the 'kick bollock and scramble' it depicts, the moments when 'just getting it on air becomes more important than what gets on air' or when 'you hear through your earpiece that something's happened, and you know most of what's been planned is about to go out the window'. He also thinks that news anchors should regularly re-experience the rough-and-tumble of reporting: 'It's a problem that the sausage machine doesn't often release, people such as Trevor [McDonald] and Michael Buerk and Peter Sissons to get the old dust under their feet. And once you become removed from the journalistic process and remain in presenter mode, you begin to lose sight of what's happening.'

The late John Stradling Thomas MP was a Tory whip, but he did a brilliant Nye Bevan impression. I recall him standing perilously on a stool in Annie's Bar, reciting the whole of a Bevan speech, with the right accent, intonation, pauses and inflections. You might have been on a windswept hill above Ebbw Vale. The speech was one of Bevan's great, lovingly rehearsed turns, about how as a boy he had thought that power was in the council, then he realised it was in parliament, then on becoming an MP he discovered it was in the cabinet. Finally he found that power actually resided in Whitehall, and hence democracy was a sham. It was a funny, exhilarating performance, and I felt privileged to enjoy it even secondhand, because a good impressionist is more evocative than any amount of scratchy black-and-white film. You couldn't do that now. The audience would have gone home ages ago. Imagine any contemporary politician trying to convince the public with a long, oratorical set piece. In November last year the prime minister gave an interview to Jeremy Paxman about Ken Livingstone. He appeared half demented. His eyes bulged. He gulped. Even more disturbingly, he suddenly remembered to smile a death's-head grimace. Later I ran into Paxman and asked him what had gone wrong. He thought - and I paraphrase - that Blair was so consumed with hatred of Livingstone that his normal speech patterns were dislocated. The medium, unable to cope with the message, had imploded. That wouldn't have happened to Nye Bevan, who would have produced a speech - 'lower than vermin' or 'dessicated calculating machine' perhaps. But Tony Blair is a creature of the modern media, and speaks the language of the daytime TV studio - cosy, cuddly, warm. He hasn't got the verbal bag of tools to do hatred. The way rhetoric has changed as the media have changed is the theme of a three-part Radio 4 series I've just finished working on. We wondered whether the formal persuasive talking of the past can survive today in a world where communication is by electronic pulses rather than by ringing voices. Nothing could be less rhetorical than email, with its sparse grammar and punctuation, minimalist vocabulary and absence even of capital letters, the equivalent of a speaker's stress. It is bland and unarousing. McLuhan talked about 'hot' and 'cool' media; email is positively frozen. But rhetoric has survived. No one who has heard the Rev Ian Paisley in full flood can doubt that, nor the power his speech has over an audience. Indeed, US evangelists use all the tricks and formulae the ancient Greeks knew. Few people in a modern business organisation have escaped the motivational speech, a form of discourse which uses some of the same devices for praising capitalism that John Wesley used for praising the Lord. Lawyers still use rhetoric, in the packed intimacy of a courtroom; George Carman is the most successful exponent today. Even in politics, rhetoric is still used - though it's now almost confined to party conferences, which are the only remaining great rallies. Gladstone's Midlothian campaign couldn't happen now; we'd all be at home watching TV. Ann Widdecombe, who has taken over the job of whipping the Tories to a fervour, told us of the tricks she uses - walking about the stage, arranging physical bits of business to attract attention, and most of all performing extempore, which is hypnotic, since the audience watches fascinated to see if she dries up. But it doesn't work as well on the page, and can look just silly on TV. Rhetoric isn't dead, but the people who use it now have to have multimedia skills as well. The Art of Rhetoric starts tomorrow at 3.45pm on Radio 4

webTitle: In with the new, down with the old

fields.bodyText: The prime minister's '21st century message' was not, one deduced, intended to offer any last-minute challenge to those masters of the political platform, Martin Luther King or Winston Churchill. It was intellectually vacuous and rhetorically impoverished; Blair's most effective device was pounding repetition. The adjective 'new' occurred no fewer than 23 times in the Guardian's edited text of the speech. And always as what Orwell calls a 'doubleplusgood' word. 'Old' occurred just once and pejoratively. So intoxicated is Blair with the idea of newness that it is sometimes difficult to see where he's going with it. 'The New Deal,' he prophesies, 'is only the first step in a new approach to welfare and work. On its foundation, we must build a new welfare system.' Is the foundation, then, to be entirely new? No pensions, no benefits, no tax relief? The brain whirls. We are not, however, allowed to linger. There is so much other novelty to admire. There is, for example, a 'new peace in Northern Ireland'. In the regions, 'new dispensations' and 'new partnerships'. In Europe, 'new bonds of connection'. Here at home, there is oodles of newness as well. Thanks to New Labour, we have 'a new national institute of clinical excellence', '37 new hospitals' and 'thousands of new doctors'. They are raring to go. 'People,' Blair declared, 'want to see the new doctors and nurses on the wards, want the new system to tackle cancer and heart disease up and running.' If, horrible thought, you had cancer or heart disease, would you want a 'new doctor', the ink still wet on his or her diploma? Or would you want a doctor who had 30 years' clinical experience treating your condition? Clearly 1.1.2000, if ever, is a time to be out with the old and on with the new. Blair's refrain was appropriate and one should not worry about what it means any more than one should worry about what exactly 'auld lang syne' is. (Every January, I resolve to look it up.) Blair's iteration of New Deal, New Labour, New Year, New Millennium, New Systems gets his big idea across. He is dedicated to change and history is on his side. Nonetheless, most of the citizens of Blair's Britain are not new. Many, in fact, may justly be termed old. And, according to recently published figures, they can confidently expect to get older. Average life expectancies, for both men and women, are moving inexorably towards 80 and beyond. And what with all the new doctors and systems tackling those pesky degenerative diseases, those who have seen it through to the new millennium may expect to live even longer. There is a troubling blind spot in Blair's vision of New Albion. He sees no place for anything 'old' - not even old people. What to do with the superannuated and underpensioned? Park them out of sight, seems to be the PM's solution. I can only speak for my own profession. I teach in Britain and in America. In Britain, at the age of 65, I must retire. American universities, like other professional institutions, may impose no age-mandatory retirement. It's federal law. You can soldier on until you drop. Many do. On the face of it, the American system looks brutal. But in my experience that is not how it works. University teachers are no more likely to suffer late-life incompetence than barristers such as George Carman who, for all his 70 years, ran rings round the opposition in court a couple of weeks ago. (If you were defending a libel suit, would you rather have Carman or a 'new lawyer'?) Many American academics land their career-best jobs in their 60s. Old teachers are, of course, expensive. They take up space required for new recruits. And they tend, given their decades of experience, to dominate key committees. But if their (American) institution wants them out, they must make a deal. A golden handshake, in other words. It cushions retirement very nicely. The abolition of age-mandatory retirement would keep a significant number of high-earners in the tax-paying sector. It would shift the onus of pension top-up from the state to the employer. Most importantly, it would retain a valuable reservoir of expertise. Since no one registers how much of Blair's Third Way is lifted from America, he could even present it as a 'radical new reform'.

In the early hours of New Year's Eve, as the attention of the world was diverted to the approach of the next millennium, a BBC announcement revealed some truly welcome news. Indeed, at this time of over-excited pronouncements, it could be described as an historic turnaround. Elevated to the exalted position of baron in the new year's honours list, John Birt is to step down two months before his declared leaving date of the end of March. In just over three weeks, Birtism at the BBC will end when the man who has led it through the dog days of the century leaves to take up his life peerage and join the House of Lords. As Lord Birt clears his desk and vacates the open-plan office he has shared with his successor Greg Dyke for the last three months, the nods and winks of those close to the DG-in-waiting who have persisted in suggesting that Birt would see in the new year and elegantly depart seem more prescient than hopeless. Through all the speculation, urging and at times ungracious insistance that Birt must go and leave Dyke in peace, the director-general remained at least on the surface resolute. Sadly we can only guess at the behind the scenes manoeuvring that the neatness of his u-turn implies. What were the terms of the trade-off? Did Dyke make clear the untenable nature of his position? Did Sir John self-sacrificingly lay down his sword and his last 60 days of power for an extra £5 on the licence fee? Did it involve a mandatory appearance at the dome? In Cambridge, at the Royal Television Society convention, he was adamant he would see out the entire six-month handover period, unconvincingly arguing that Dyke would need all the assistance he could give. Echoing the Queen, by publicly refusing to countenance abdication, though the successor may wish it with all his heart and the public might believe it to be inevitable, Sir John was not for moving. Even when, after the conference, briefings from government suggested a solution involving elevation and grandeur might be acceptable, his position remained firm. It would have been unseemly, of course, for Lord Birt to rush straight from the editorial impartiality of the BBC into a Labour whip in the Lords. Unseemly and unnecessarily provocative for a Tory party sufficiently beleaguered to make further accusations of bias at the Beeb all too inevitable. He will sit on the cross benches (as revealed by this paper last year) where, we may fondly hope, he will soon be provoked into some stirring attacks on his former policies, much as Duke Hussey so eloquently turned on his former protege in a debate on the future of public service broadcasting last year. There will be much to concern him. A broadcasting act seems certain to be scheduled early in the next parliament. Birt's understanding of digital television will hopefully help the politicians' loose grasp of the technology. Perhaps during his maiden speech, the remaining slumbering Lords will be treated to a Birt special; complete with overhead projector, bullet points and clips from the costume drama du jour. Followed naturally by a thorough background briefing (or translation) from a team of corporate press officers. If the new year cannot be guaranteed to bring the BBC a substantial slug of digital licence fee income to the tune of the £700m it has requested, then at least the government can claim to have performed this small miracle, of contriving a happy and graceful solution to the never justifiable two leaders in one office dilemma. Should the now widely predicted across the board increase in the licence fee replace Gavyn Davies' digital supplement and finally materialise before the end of January, Dyke will be able to take over in February with the minimum of conflict. It's probably the best solution broadcasting could have hoped from the government. More gratifying than the well-deserved OBE to media hack Ray Snoddy for services to explaining convergence to politicians, more satisfying somehow than ITN chief executive Stewart Purvis's CBE for struggling valiantly against the move of News at Ten and certainly more edifying than the CBE to News Corporation's chief spin doctor, Jane Reed, for services to creating a better image for Rupert Murdoch. If Lord Birt seems to have shown, in this his last roll of the corporate dice, a rash determination to stay on till the final curtain, his reward should be that he considers himself amply recompensed by the government with a fancy costume and the chance to make a suitably damning condemnation of his enemies. Perhaps it's just because it's the panto season, but the picture of Baron not-so-Hard-Up strutting his ermine-clad stuff in the Lords should gladden even the least forgiving of his detractors' hearts.

The Tories have been having such rotten luck recently that you almost feel sorry for them. For months now, their media managers have had about as much trouble generating a positive headline as Neil Hamilton's barrister had getting a word in edgeways with Mohamed Al Fayed. Some elements of the recent run of desperately unhelpful headlines - such as those spawned by the disaster-courting dishonourable former member for Tatton - were the result of a bumper harvest of bad apples, and can hardly be blamed on the luckless party leadership. But in so many day-to-day issues of general political policy, the Tories are constantly coming nowhere in the race for a positive spin on the front pages - even in those papers on whose support it could traditionally count. So when they managed to secure the (unpaid) services of 15 eminent economists to serve on an advisory panel for the beleaguered Tory high command, it was rightly seen as something of a coup. But inept handling of the announcement by a junior party official turned what should have been a minor victory into a major defeat, precipitating the resignation of a prominent member of the committee on the day his appointment was announced. It was yet another Tory fiasco. The 15 names on the Conservative press release were, to most journalists, impressive-sounding but unknown. One name, however, stood out - that of the US economist, Irwin Stelzer. Any mention of Stelzer's name in a British political context always pricks the attention of Westminster-watchers, for Stelzer is not simply the director of a prominent Washington free market-oriented think tank, but one of the few close confidants of a certain Rupert Murdoch. Stelzer, who has known and advised Murdoch for over 20 years, writes columns in the Murdoch-owned New York Post and Sunday Times and is a super-lobbyist on behalf of the media magnet. Almost anywhere around the world where a big Murdoch deal is being pulled off Stelzer's name will not be far from the action. He has been called Murdoch's secret agent. It was doubly interesting that Stelzer should be associated now with the Tories. He is an admirer of Gordon Brown, and a frequent visitor to Downing Street. He is also a staunch Thatcherite who has little time for the political and economic fudges that have stalked the Conservatives since her departure. Murdoch's stable of newspapers has broadly abandoned the Tories, having given themselves up to the prevailing new Labour wind. Stelzer was in on the whole process - reportedly party to a secret, and always-denied deal done between Murdoch and Blair in which the Sun's support for new Labour was guaranteed, provided Blair backed off from outright support of the single currency in the short term. It was a stroke of unseasonal bad luck which made the welcoming of a Murdoch confidant into the bossom of the Conservatives a new year banana skin. The former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, had chosen the same day to launch a vicious broadside against the current leadership, and much of the Westminster press gallery was in Tory meltdown (again) mode. But it was the middle of the holiday period and most publications were operating on skeleton rotas - meaning that Stelzer's appointment, although interesting to the hacks, was surely seen as something of a low priority. But at the Financial Times political desk Cathy Newman's interest was aroused. Perhaps it was her background in media matters - until recently, she was the FT's media correspondent - but whatever the reason, she thought that Stelzer's involvement with the Tories was worthy of note. She sought further comment from Conservative sources, and was rewarded by an off-the-record quote from an adviser to the shadow chancellor Francis Maude - who had assembled the panel. In a comment which was attributed to an 'aide' in the next day's edition, the Maude team member said: 'We're not claiming that Murdoch is back with us or anything of the kind. But it is encouraging that someone so close to Murdoch is happy to sit on our council.' As soon as he read the story in Washington, Stelzer was furious. Despite his close association with the News Corp chief, he hates to be portrayed as a Murdoch frontman, and he dashed off an acidic resignation letter to Maude. 'I do hope that the remaining members [of the committee] will help you to improve the forecasting skills that led you to predict a recession immediately before the nation's rate of economic growth soared and unemployment began to fall,' he concluded acidly. Once again, the Tories were rewarded with a crop of negative headlines. With luckless timing that would have been dismissed as unbelievable had it appeared in a work of political fiction, the Stelzer story broke just as news emerged of further criticism of Hague - this time by his predecessor, John Major. Stelzer himself could not avoid a smile to himself. Sitting at home in his Washington apartment, he remarked that the Tories seem to be getting desperate in their search for a good story. Reflecting on the tale over the weekend, he suggests that the Conservative party must think long and hard about what it stands for if it is to regain the confidence of the traditionally 'Tory' press. Although Stelzer stresses once again that he can't speak for Murdoch, the News International stable is clearly in this category. 'I assume media people are intelligent, and there's no reason to believe they are of less than average intelligence, it seems to me the way any politician gets support of media people is through attractive, coherent policies,' he says. As far as Stelzer is concerned, one area where Tory policy is clearly neither attractive nor coherent is European monetary union - a subject close to his heart (he is currently in the process of preparing a Hudson Institute book on European integration). Labour's position of entering economic union when certain criteria are met, Stelzer says, is at least principled - even though he doesn't believe in it. Hague's position is not to enter EMU within a decade. 'It's very hard to ride into battle with the banner 'I want to wait three years longer than Blair wants to wait',' Stelzer says. In some of Stelzer's frequent conversations with Blair, the prime minister has revealed that he can at least understand those who sustain an implacable opposition to the single currency. Michael Portillo, Stelzer suggests, did at least have a position: 'No, never.' It would be one that Hague would do well at least to consider: 'The more you are against it the closer you are to a principle,' Stelzer says. While Hague flounders, Blair's stance is supported by a coherent principle while delivering 'wiggle room' - that all-important room for manoeuvre that all politicians crave.

At the end of the film When We Were Kings, Norman Mailer recalls that his last meeting with Muhammad Ali was at an Esquire party in New York. As we left the cinema my friend Al recalled the line and said: 'What would you say these days? The last time I saw Jamie Theakston, he was at an Esquire party... ' And that is why the job of Esquire editor must be fraught with gloom. Every time you step into your office you are made aware of the huge weight of publishing history resting on your shoulders. The ghost of 1960s US Esquire must sit in the corner, sniffing haughtily as you bung yet another Caprice shoot on the cover and in your heart you must know it will shake its head at almost everything you do. Because, quite simply, 1960s US Esquire was the greatest magazine in the world. Now, Peter Howarth the present editor, says he wants to rediscover that magic. He has a lot to live up to. Which other magazine could claim to have created a new form of journalism and discovered Tom Wolfe and Norman Mailer? Which other magazine could boast writers such as Truman Capote, Vladimir Nabokov, Allen Ginsberg and Edward Albee, and yet be confident enough to attack Capote on its own front page? Esquire was the first mainstream US magazine to take an anti-Vietnam war stance. It campaigned for Muhammad Ali's right to fight. It supported actors such as Jack Nicholson and Dustin Hoffman. It was vilified by Nixon and praised by Warhol and managed to disregard them both. In large part, its place in history was guaranteed by its covers. In 1962, editor Harold Hayes abandoned the idea of using the in-house art department to create his cover and turned to a Madison Avenue advertising executive called George Lois. Lois wanted to create powerful images that sold the magazine without reference to the tedious list of features - 'burn off your belly!', '1,000 ways to be wicked!', 'this year's Bond girl - as you've never seen her before!' - that dominate men's magazine covers these days. It was Lois who persuaded Ali to pose like St Sebastian and who dared to put out an all-black cover with the phrase 'Oh my God - we hit a little girl' on the issue that carried the true story of M Company in Vietnam. It was also Lois who was mainly responsible for the way Esquire's UK editor Peter Howarth felt three months ago when looking at yet another bikini blonde on his cover. 'I was ashamed,' he says. 'My wife looked at the cover I'd brought home and I felt embarrassed. Around the same time, a friend of mine who runs a bar round the corner told me that he can't leave copies of Esquire out when his friends come round because of the cover. In that issue we had a feature from the only journalist to train with the All Blacks and I was sitting at Twickenham with our deputy managing director and wondered how many people here would have known we had that kind of feature. I figured probably none of them.' Howarth was so ashamed that he did something about it. He decided to redesign his magazine, abandoning his 'girl in pants' cover policy completely and replacing it with a head and shoulders shot of the month's cover star. He decided to put his cover lines on a removable strip which can be thrown away once the magazine has been bought, leaving a pure image of the woman or - much more significantly - the man that Esquire has chosen this month. Because Howarth has also decided to abandon the recently accepted market wisdom that it's only chicks on the cover who sell, and that's why this month's Esquire cover star - on sale next week - is Johnny Depp. 'We have this heritage that we publish good writing and great art and that had been lost,' he explains. 'I mean, it's all very well publishing John Updike in the 60s, but we've got some great writers now. We publish people like Martin Amis but we also use the Alex Ferguson principle of playing Eric Cantona alongside Ryan Giggs. That's why we also use new names such as Giles Foden and Matt Seaton, or James Parker or a TV documentary maker called Eamonn O'Neil who does all our investigative stuff. 'People like that are exciting. They are the new Tom Wolfes. British Esquire should be about finding the new New Journalism. It's just that our covers didn't suggest that you were holding that sort of magazine in your hands. If we were the only men's magazine in the market, like Arena was in 1985, you could put whatever you wanted on the cover. But we're not. The ones that sell the most are the ones with the most childish content and the most girls with the least clothes. Our covers suggested we were like them and put off the sort of reader we wanted to attract.' And yet, surely something that is accepted market wisdom is usually accepted for a reason. Loaded recently put Dennis Hopper on the cover and saw its circulation instantly dip by about 50,000. The IPC board panicked and a missive shot down to Loaded's offices asking them to redress the situation sharpish. Isn't Howarth's plucky stance merely the doomed effort of a worthy editor to buck the inevitable? Won't he be on the phone to Caprice's agent by April? 'The board has given me a year,' he says. 'Well, they've given me forever, but I have said to them that you can't judge this in any less time than a year and they backed me, which was very brave of them. The intention is not to lose circulation, and I think that's achievable. 'I should say that this doesn't mean we're abandoning having women in the magazine. This is not a moral crusade. Even Harold Hayes had shoots with Raquel Welch and Angie Dickinson alongside pieces by Wolfe and Mailer. If we were to go down [in circulation], however, then it becomes interesting. Our advertisers are the kind of people who buy predominately on environment. Prada doesn't buy numbers or it would be advertising in FHM. But it isn't. 'The question is, when do the numbers stop making sense? Given the momentum of the title over the last eight months, I'm convinced our readers will stay with us and we can keep selling over 100,000.' He's already dipped his toe into the water with the international edition of the magazine's last issue. In the UK the cover star was model Kate Groombridge, who sat naked against a white background. Overseas the cover star was Damon Albarn, that issue's big interview. Already, the overseas change has produced results. Both Prada and Hugo Boss, Howarth says, have welcomed the move and hope Esquire will move even further towards its 60s character. The big question, of course, is how the UK reader will react. Do any liberal British men reading this feel prompted to go out and buy Esquire? Over to you.

It surely stands as one of the most damning mea culpas ever issued by a newspaper, let alone America's fourth largest. But the Los Angeles Times has just printed a 14-page, 32,000-word indictment of its own operating practices. Written by a Pulitzer prize-winning staffer, David Shaw, the front page report not only attacked a profit sharing deal between the paper's Sunday magazine and a new, multi-million dollar sports centre - itself the subject of a bumper edition published last October - as 'a tangled tale of ignorance and arrogance', but also cast a harsh light on the paper's editor Michael Parks, its publisher Kathryn Downing, and chief executive Mark Willes. It was not the kind of confession you would expect from a British newspaper but then here there has yet to be such a high-velocity, head-on collision between the business of newspapers and the objective, independent principles of journalism. The report, which was not seen by the editor or publisher prior to publication, was designed to re-establish the paper's 'bond of trust' with its readership - a bond its reporters felt had been badly sullied. As a result of the deal with the Staples Centre, and the ensuing controversy, Shaw wrote: 'The Times' credibility and integrity - ultimately the only commodities a newspaper has to offer - have been severely compromised at a time when public confidence in the press is already in deep decline.' On October 10, the LA Times published an unusually large, 164-page magazine supplement entirely devoted to the Staples sports arena in downtown Los Angeles without revealing to its readership, or its own reporters, that the $2m the issue raised in advertising revenue would be split between the paper and its subject. Nor was it revealed that the ads were sold with the assistance of the Staples ad staff or that the Times is a corporate sponsor of the arena and had committed to pay $1.6m in cash and free advertising for five years in exchange for 'joint revenue opportunities' - such as a special magazine issue - and a permanent corporate box. What may have seemed like a bright, profit-boosting idea to the paper's new publisher, Kathryn Downing, soon dimmed when word of the scheme leaked out to the city's alternative weekly, the New Times. Amid intense internal protest, the publisher and editors maintained the arrangement had not influenced their coverage but the issue soon came to be seen as the ugly tip of an ethical iceberg that threatened to undermine the paper's integrity and reputation. The paper's 300 reporters signed a petition demanding that Downing - who had no experience in newspapers and had only been in the job six months - apologise and undertake a thorough review that would unearth any other dubious financial relationships. Unfortunately for Downing, it did. The Staples issue 'creates an impression that maybe the editorial independence of the newsroom is up for grabs and maybe that independence has to be proven now,' says Tom Rosenstiel, director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism in Washington DC. 'Even if it's not true, readers might wonder: 'Did they kill critical stories?' or 'Maybe they didn't assign tough ones'.' The furore grew with a contribution from former LA Times publisher, Otis Chandler, scion of the family that has had a controlling stake in the newspaper since 1882. Chandler called the management's behaviour 'unbelievably stupid and unprofessional' and said the episode was the 'most serious single threat to the future survival and growth of the paper'. Downing retorted that Chandler was 'angry and bitter'. Ultimately, Downing did apologise but was hardly able to instill much confidence when she revealed that the profit-sharing arrangement and her failure to reveal it came from her 'fundamental misunderstanding' of a publisher's role and ignorance of newspaper ethics. Nor did the paper's editor look much better - he said he knew of the deal after the magazine was completed but before it was distributed and yet failed to stop delivery or notify readers. 'Clearly, I underestimated the impact of the Staples arrangement on our credibility, on the journalistic ethos that we foster, on our standing in the community and in the profession,' Parks told Shaw. 'And for all those things I have profound regret.' Although the investigation did not find a smoking gun, it did identify an incremental evolution of mistakes that led to the fiasco. The first inkling of the future disaster came in 1995 when the paper's parent, Times Mirror, hired Mark Willes - a former General Mills executive who had earned the title Cap'n Crunch for his vigorous cost-cutting methods at the food giant - to re-invent the business of running a newspaper. Under his predecessor, Chandler (a champion surfer, a former shot-putter who came within inches of the world record, a racing-car driver and big-game hunter), the paper had gained in stature but remained junior to the big three, the New York Times, the Washington Post and the Wall Street Journal, in terms of reach and importance. During Chandler's 30-year tenure, he behaved like a proprietor of the old school. He lavished money on the paper - it stationed 14 correspondents and photographers in the Soviet Union during the collapse of communism - and built up a considerable circulation, peaking at 1.2m in 1990. But in the Californian recession of the early nineties, the LA Times began haemorrhaging money and its board members and stockholders (largely made up of Chandlers) became increasingly unhappy with the cost of fulfilling Otis's dream to knock the New York Times 'off its perch'. Enter Willes as publisher and chief executive, a man with the stated intention to 'blow up' - with a 'bazooka' if necessary - the wall that separates the newsroom from the business side of the paper. Instrumental to his plan to boost circulation and profits and drive up the stock price, was the aim that the business concerns of the paper would now be a regular part of newsroom decisions, editors would be required to work closely with advertising staff identifying stories that would appeal to advertisers, and different sections of the paper would operate as separate business units. Despite widespread warnings at the time that applying his consumer product savvy to a newspaper could upset the fine balance between editorial and advertising, Willes advanced his plan. The book review section, for instance, would now give special consideration to books published by houses with large advertising budgets. Willes and his team had many other ideas, many of which are only now surfacing: the paper received a sales commission for books sold by Barnes & Noble if the reader of a Times online book review clicked over to the retailer. Man agement had proposed publication of a special section on a local car racetrack for which the track would receive a commission for ads it sold in the paper. Shaw's report also noted that the paper devoted heavy coverage to conferences and other events it sponsored and that the news staff had helped organise. Although none of these examples is spectacularly heinous, and similar changes have been instituted at other newspapers as they try to find new revenue and staunch declining circulations, the irony of the Times affair is that it seems to have been caused by too little communication between business and editorial, not too much. Nor have Willes' reforms necessarily worked. Though Times Mirror's stock price has tripled since 1995 after he cut costs and sold assets, circulation of the LA Times remains flat at 1m and he has yet to find a radical cure for what ails the business. 'Newspapers that don't take appropriate risks to meet the challenge of a rapidly changing media environment are doomed to die,' he says. In the end, the profit-sharing agreement obliged the Times to pay Staples Center about $300,000; a relatively small amount of money for a paper that enjoys almost $1bn a year in advertising revenue. But the damage to its reputation, particularly in a country where the press sees itself as having explicit constitutional significance and full disclosure, has been marked. 'The wall [between the newsroom and business] used to represent a clear protection of editorial integrity and independence from the influence of advertisers,' Downing said in a statement, before acknowledging that the cultural change at the paper did not include putting into place 'protocols to replace what we took away'. In clarification of its journalistic principles, and the rules of engagement between the editorial and business sides, the paper published a manifesto of intent, including one commitment reading: 'advertising may not be co-ordinated with or sold against specific stories or graphics in a way that raises questions of credibility of integrity'. Another said that if 'the editorial mission and the commercial interests of the Times conflict, editorial integrity will always come first'. While the new guidelines offer some solace and all those in positions of power at the paper now appear to agree the whole affair was a colossal blunder, Shaw concluded his exhaustive inquiry expressing scepticism at Downing's assertion that the Times would emerge better after the Staples debacle. 'Is she right?' David Shaw asked. 'Or will the guidelines be followed diligently only until profit margins fall again and pressure for new revenue intensifies?'

On New Year's day Vladimir Putin scrapped his plans to celebrate the millennium in Moscow and set off instead for Chechnya to congratulate the troops on the splendid job they were doing. In military terms that might suggest he is easily satisfied, for the quick resolution of the war expected last month shows little sign of arriving; the rebels are far from quelled, Grozny is, as we write, yet to be taken and more bloody conflict, in line with this weekend's escalation, is likely before Russia gets its way. But undoubtedly in terms of Mr Putin's own advancement, the armed forces have done a good job indeed. His breathtaking ascent from obscurity to the role of acting president - and more than that, president presumptive, as from the end of March - may not be exclusively due to the war in Chechnya, but that has clearly been its most powerful ingredient. Indeed, promoting Mr Putin, may be what this second Chechen war is all about. That is not just because getting tough with the Chechens has played so well with Russian public opinion: it is also because Mr Putin looks clear-headed, decisive, indeed ruthless, when the leadership of the country in the closing years of President Yeltsin has looked utterly the reverse. He is riding so high in the polls because he promises order to a disordered country. He promises the smack of firm government, delivered if need be with a mailed fist. Once that was Boris Yeltsin's appeal, when with the kind of courage which borders on foolhardiness, he climbed on the tank in 1991 to rout the projected putsch against Gorbachev; and again as he successfully engineered the end of Communist rule. For their own political reasons - largely the fear of something still worse - western leaders have been doing their best in the late 90s to pretend that Yeltsin was still the deci sive leader of earlier days, when in fact he had been reduced, by ill-health compounded by drink, to a capricious, confused and sometimes literally tottering figure. So the economy foundered and the standards of daily life grew worse rather than better, and people increasingly yearned for the stability of communist times: a development to which the west has contributed by insisting on economic solutions which put ideology first and left the easing of change, which is part of all practical politics, limping woefully behind. Crime and corruption flourished. If this was the `genius' which some on the right in Britain continue to see in Yeltsin, it was genius of a fitful and sozzled kind. And yet the end game, whoever devised it, has indeed had a touch of genius about it. The singling out of Vladimir Putin. The confection of a political party which has no greater remit than to support what he says and does. Elections for the duma which though democratic in name were profoundly undemocratic in practice, with a television coverage that was more party political broadcast on behalf of Unity than open democratic debate. And now the near-perfect scenario for elections in March rather than June, with no time for his country's uncharacteristic new year optimism to shrivel. And for Boris Yeltsin himself, a permanent exoneration for whatever he may have done; immunity from prosecution and an absolute guarantee of no questions asked, which given the suspicions hanging over him, he urgently needed; a fat pension and other perks to ensure a life of safety and comfort for the rest of his days. Most western tributes to him as he departs have so far been sensibly muted. Whatever Mr Putin may now produce, it was more than time for Russia to come under new management.

Russia's centre-left opposition has been plunged into disarray by Boris Yeltsin's snap resignation designed to boost the presidential prospects of his protege, Vladimir Putin. Reeling from the New Year's Eve coup, the opposition appears at a loss about how to mount a credible challenge to the acting president and prime minister. The presidential election is expected on March 26 - three months earlier than scheduled. And the campaign effectively kicked off on New Year's Day, with Mr Putin shown live on state television during a morale-boosting visit to Russian troops in Chechnya. 'Russia thanks you,' he told Russian officers and soldiers. Already the darling of the military because of his hard line on Chechnya, Mr Putin burnished his army credentials further by telling the top brass and the country that the military and not the politicians would decide on the pace and conduct of the war. However, Mr Putin faces three declared candidates in the race for the Kremlin: Yevgeny Primakov, the former prime minister and foreign minister, Grigory Yavlinsky, the liberals' leader, and Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the extreme nationalist. It is also assumed that Gennady Zyuganov, the Communist party's leader who lost to Mr Yeltsin in 1996, will also stand. The first three all declared their candidatures just before the elections to the duma two weeks ago in an attempt to enhance their vote. But only the Communist vote stood up, although they are 35 seats worse off in the new parlia ment, which is dominated by centrists and promises far greater support for Mr Putin than Mr Yeltsin ever enjoyed. Can Mr Putin be stopped? Mr Yavlinsky's candidacy can be effectively discounted, and Mr Putin's main opposition will come from the centre-left, the Communists and the Fatherland-All Russia movement (OVR) of Mr Primakov and the Moscow mayor, Yuri Luzhkov. The former Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, responded to the Yeltsin resignation by urging the centre-left to unite behind a single candidate, Mr Primakov, to maximise the vote against Mr Putin. The Communists are the best organised and most disciplined party machine in Russia and could probably guarantee Mr Primakov a quarter of the electorate. But that would entail Mr Zyuganov eating humble pie and standing aside. But despite Mr Primakov's declared candidacy two weeks ago, it is no longer clear if he will run. Mr Luzhkov declined to endorse Mr Primakov last Friday, saying there would need to be 'consultations'. Moreover, the number three in the OVR, Vladimir Yakovlev, the mayor of Russia's second city, St Petersburg, faces re-election in May and is already flirting with the Putin camp. Gennady Seleznev, the Communist speaker of the outgoing duma says frankly that Mr Putin looks unbeatable. The interim president has returned the compliment by voicing support for the Communist in his bid to be governor of the greater Moscow region. In short, while the opposition fractures in the face of the Putin phenomenon, the acting president and prime minister is busy building a broader support base - ambitious politicians of all stripes are suddenly eager to bask in his glory. State television propaganda has been hugely instrumental in building up Mr Putin and in securing the strong showing of his allies in the duma election. The next three months will see a continuation of that campaign. And if Mr Primakov, 70, confirms his candidacy, he will be painted as an elderly, unreconstructed communist by state television. At the moment, the question is not whether Mr Putin can be beaten, but whether the opposition can force him into a second round by denying him an outright victory on March 26.

webTitle: Diana's landmine crusade put Tories in a panic

fields.bodyText: A graphic account of how John Major's government was gripped by panic over Princess Diana's uncompromising stance on a worldwide ban on landmines is revealed in previously secret diplomatic cables. They were sent by American ambassadors to the US secretary of state, Madeline Albright, during the princess's visit to Angola. They reveal that the Americans believed Diana had 'bested' John Major and the foreign secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, after a junior defence minister, Earl Howe, had accused her of being a 'loose cannon'. They also contain a revealing insight into how she refused to 'wine and dine' the social elite and snubbed the daughter of an African king in favour of meeting the Angolan people. Such attitudes caused considerable embarrassment for the British ambassador in Angola, Roger Hart, who had to sneak in VIP guests to eat char sui and bean sprouts with the princess. The trip, in January 1997, caused huge controversy in the press when she appeared to endorse Labour's policy of a worldwide ban on landmines. The US cables show that the Americans - who later cooled on the idea of a ban - could scarcely conceal their delight at her strong stance and even told the British ambassador in Angola what a great success her visit had been. Blow-by-blow accounts of the princess's controversial visit were sent to Ms Albright from Admiral William Crowe, then US ambassador to Britain, and Donald Steinberg, then US ambassador to Angola. The cables released to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act would be banned from publication in Britain until 2072 because of their mention of the royal family. Admiral Crowe's cable - written in the same colourful language as his outspoken comments about the royals and William Hague after Diana's death - is headed 'Princess Di trips political landmine'. 'Controversy and/or room for misunderstanding was inherent in the princess's trip' because the British Red Cross wanted an immediate worldwide ban on anti-personnel mines, while the government's position was that Britain would not support a ban until all countries had signed a deal. Once the princess had made her statement supporting a worldwide ban, she was attacked by Earl Howe for being 'ill-informed on the issue of anti-personnel mines' and a 'loose cannon' ' that Her Majesty's government did not need'. Admiral Crowe says: 'Government officials immediately scrambled to repair the public relations damage and issued statements affirming the government's commitment to 'working toward a worldwide ban on landmines'.' A Downing Street spokesman was quoted as claiming there had been a 'misunderstanding' and that the princess's remarks were not 'inconsistent with government policy'. He adds: 'Labour party officials used the flap to highlight differences between Labour and the Conservative government on the landmine issue.' Mr Steinberg tells Ms Albright from Luanda that by the time the three-day trip had finished the princess had 'bested a political furore in London', adding that Mr Major and Mr Rifkind had 'stepped in to cool things off'. He also reports approvingly of how she shunned celebrity status. 'She wanted a serious visit, not to be seen wining and dining with the social elite. The daughter of the king of the Lundas wanted to meet with her British counterpart, but failed. The princess accepted a dinner invitation hosted by first lady Ana Paula Dos Santos (the Angolan president's wife) on condition that it be small (26 guests ate from a catered Chinese food buffet) short (it ended at 8.10pm) and there be no press or speeches. Hart (the British ambassador) managed to get the local directors of Shell, BP and De Beers invited. 'Hart himself held only a dinner for her and Red Cross officials.' The reports also discloses that Mr Major's government had the added problem that Diana had been fully briefed of the British position by the foreign office and the visit had been personally approved by the Queen. 'For her part, the princess was looking for a new public cause to promote that would not conflict with the interests of other members of the royal family.' The US ambassador's report adds that originally the Red Cross wanted to send her to Vietnam or Cambodia but this was ruled out by the foreign office as too dangerous. Mr Steinberg concludes: 'She was excited about the results and talking about more visits to Vietnam, Cambodia, Kuwait and return engagement in Angola. No one can come to Angola and see the human devastation caused by landmines and not be moved. We have told the British ambassador how seriously the United States' government takes this problem and how much we appreciate Diana's support.'

At the age of 18, Sara Denver set her heart on becoming a nurse and embarked on almost four years of training - first a degree, then a course to specialise in cardiothoracic intensive care. 'I loved my job, I was doing something practical and I enjoyed working with people.' After spending such a long time training, it never occurred to her that she would want to change, particularly to a career which would involve an even longer period of study. But a chance conversation with a disaffected doctor who had decided to jettison medicine in favour of law had a profound effect on her. She began to find out as much as she could about training and what a job as a solicitor would entail. 'I wanted to find out as much as I could, as once you've left a career it's quite hard to go back to it.' Research completed, she decided that law would suit her perfectly. And she hoped that when she qualified she would be able to use some of her skills gained in the NHS to specialise in medical negligence cases. Another protracted training stint followed - this time for five years - with a one-year law conversion course then two years of legal practice and finally a two-year training contract with a firm of solicitors. 'I qualified in September and it feels great. I loved the challenge of studying for something new; law was something I really wanted to do for myself but at the same time I think I've chosen something useful.' While she doesn't know of many lawyers who have changed career direction, Denver, 32, can think of many colleagues from medicine who are now doing different jobs. She says an increasing number of medical negligence cases are being taken out, which means an abundant supply of work is likely. 'I don't know whether the incidences of negligence are increasing or whether people are becoming more aware of legal action as an option.' She is certain there won't be any more lightning career changes. 'This is it now. I'm so much happier in this career; I feel I can really make a difference to people. I would recommend changing direction to anyone. Explore the options thoroughly, but don't be afraid of change.'

webTitle: The difference between men and women

fields.bodyText: 1. He will completely screw your head up every second that YOU are with him 2. You ARE a mind reader... never forget it, and never tell him any different 3. No man is SPECIAL, they all turn out the same in the end 4. You can NEVER ask him for any more commitment than he's already giving you 5.
